{{For|other uses of the name|Elene (disambiguation)}} {{Italic title}} '''''Elene''''' is a [[poem]] in [[Old English]], that is sometimes known as '''''Saint Helena Finds the True Cross'''''. It was translated from a [[Latin]] text and is the longest of [[Cynewulf]]'s four signed poems. It is the fifth of six poems appearing in the [[Vercelli book|Vercelli manuscript]], which also contains ''[[The Fates of the Apostles]]'', ''[[Andreas]]'', ''[[Soul and Body I]]'', the ''Homiletic Fragment I'' and ''[[Dream of the Rood]]''. The poem is the first English account of the finding of the [[True Cross|Holy Cross]] by [[Helena (empress)|Saint Helena]], the mother of [[Emperor Constantine]]. The poem was written by Cynewulf some time between 750 and the tenth century. <!-- (Cameron 1987) --> It is written in a [[West Saxon dialect (Old English)|West Saxon]] [[dialect]], but certain Anglianisms and metrical evidence concerning false rhymes suggest it was written in an [[Old English|Anglian]] rather than Saxon dialect. It is 1,321 lines long.
== Cynewulf ==
{{Main article|Cynewulf}} Cynewulf’s signature, which is always in [[rune]]s, appears on ''[[Christ II]]'', ''[[Juliana (poem)|Juliana]]'', ''[[The Fates of the Apostles]]'' and ''Elene''. The dialect in his poems suggests that he was either [[Mercia]]n or [[Northumbria]]n.<!-- (Bjork 1998) --> He was probably most active around the late 8th and early 9th centuries, though there is other research to support that he was active between the late 9th and late 10th centuries.
Cynewulf’s true identity is still unknown, but there have been efforts to narrow down the list of possible poets. The four most favored candidates are [[Cynewulf of Lindisfarne|Cynewulf, who was the bishop of Lindisfarne]] in Northumbria in around 783; Cynulf, a [[priest]] (ca. 803); Cynewulf, the father of [[Cyneweard of Glastonbury|Bishop Cyuneweard of Wells]], who died in 975; and Cenwulf, an [[abbot]] of [[Peterborough Cathedral|Peterborough Abbey]] in around 1006).<!-- (Bjork 1998) --> There is not enough evidence to support any of these claims.
== Manuscript ==
''Elene'' is contained in the ''[[Vercelli Book]]'', appearing on fol. 121a-133b.
== Plot summary ==
The story is loosely based on historical events and takes place within an [[anachronistic]] setting that amalgamates wars of the fourth-century involving the [[Roman army|Romans]], the [[Huns]] and the [[Franks]]. ''Elene'' fits into a subgenre of ''[[inventio]]'', the search for sacrosanct [[relic]]s of the saints. Cynewulf’s source for the legend of St. Helena's Finding of the Cross was probably the ''Acta Cyriaci'' and a version of it is written in the ''[[Acta Sanctorum]]'' for May 4.
The poem begins with [[Constantine the Great|Constantine, emperor of Rome]], riding out to battle the Huns and Hrethgoths. He is a mighty king made strong by God, though he is not aware of the Christian God yet. He sees a vision in the sky and he is told that he will halt his enemies with the symbol that is shown to him by the heavens. The battle begins and Constantine reveals the symbol that he was shown, a [[Christian cross|cross]]. The cross sends his enemies running in all directions and they are easily defeated by the Romans.
Constantine returns home and addresses an assembly on whether they know the meaning of the symbol that saved his people. Only the wisest know that the cross is the symbol of the Lord in Heaven, [[Jesus|Jesus Christ]]. Constantine is [[Baptism|baptized]] and becomes a devout [[Christianity|Christian]], due to his experience. He learns from the [[Bible]] how and where Christ was killed, so he orders Helen, his mother, to lead an army to the land of the [[Judaism|Jews]] to find where the true cross is buried. She leads an army of men onto a ship and begins the journey to [[Israel]].
Once in the city of [[Jerusalem]], she calls an assembly of sage Jews and scorns them for having condemned Jesus to death, leaving them wondering what they have done to anger the queen. Judas tells his fellow Jews that he knows the queen searches for the cross. Judas was brought up on Christian teachings, and his brother [[Saint Stephen|Stephen]] was stoned to death for being a Christian. The Jews refuse to help Helen find the cross, so she threatens them with death. Frightened, they hand over Judas. He also refuses to tell her where it is, so she locks him in a dark prison for seven days without food. On the seventh day he cries out that he cannot take the torture any longer and will reveal where the cross is. He leads the queen to the hill where Jesus was crucified.
[[Judas Cyriacus|Judas]] converts to Christianity in a passionate speech to God acknowledging Jesus as his Savior. God gives Judas a smoke sign in the sky, which convinces him of his new-found belief. He digs and finds three crosses. A crowd forms, but no one knows which of the three was the cross of Christ. They set the crosses up in the city hoping that Christ would show them the truth. A corpse is brought forth, and each cross is held over him. The third cross brings him back to life.
[[Satan]] appears in grotesque form angry that he has had a soul stolen from him. Judas cleverly argues with Satan with his new faith, but Satan leaves with a threat that he will raise up a king to retaliate. Helen sends word home to Constantine, who tells her to build a [[Church (building)|church]] on the hillside where the crosses were found. She encases the true cross in [[gold]] and jewels and places it in the church. Judas is baptized and puts away his false religion. He is appointed to priesthood and is renamed Cyriacus because of his rebirth.
Helen then decides she needs to find the nails that held Christ up on the cross. Cyriacus searches for them, and God again gives him a sign in the form of fire to show where they are buried. Helen receives the gift with tears of joy, and the [[Holy Spirit]] fills her with the gift of wisdom and forever protects the saint. She goes to a wise man to find out how she should use the nails, and he advises her to use them in the bit of Constantine’s horse so that he would always be victorious in battle. The [[epilogue]] of the poem is devoted to the personal reflection of Cynewulf and his interpretation of [[Doomsday event|Doomsday]]. Cynewulf tells of how he has experienced a spiritual metamorphosis. His depiction of the [[Last Judgement]] resembles a sort of [[Purgatory]] where people are divided into three groups, two of which undergo cleansing to reach salvation, while the third is damned to eternal [[Hell]].
== Analysis ==
Helen is not the typical passive Old English heroine. She is strong and autonomous, more like the women in [[Old Norse literature]] rather than the Graeco-Roman saints.<!-- (Olsen 224) --> Old Norse heroines are strong, assertive, and persuade physically instead of verbally. Cynewulf purposely wanted his audience to view Helen as a strong individual. He does not include her death in the poem as the [[Latin]] version does and he does not have her submitting to Constantine and Cyriacus as she does in the Latin version. In fact it is the opposite. We see Cyriacus completely submitting himself to Helen: ''hæfde Ciriacus / eall gefylled swa him seo æðele bebead, / wifes willan'' (line 1129b), ''('Cyriacus had completely done as the noble woman bade him to do, the will of the woman')''.<!-- (Olsen 224) -->
Helen can be understood as an [[allegory]] of the [[Christian Church]] and its mission to lead men to salvation through acceptance of the Cross.<!-- (Hermann 99) --> Literally, her mission is to find the true cross, but allegorically, her mission is to [[Evangelism|evangelize]] the Jews. Helen is referred to as a warrior queen and she has an army of warriors, but they never fight. The warriors are there to subjugate a powerful enemy, which could be Satan or non-believers. Judas and Helen are an allegory for the relationship of the Church with its members. Judas’s dialogue reveals him to be of the human condition; he has the capacity for saintliness and wickedness.<!-- (Bjork 1985, 62) -->
[[Anti-Semitism]] is a topic of discussion for scholars regarding the poem: Elene’s oppressive tactics towards the Jewish elders are rewarded in the end.<ref>See Fulk 2003, p.99</ref> A [[Marxist]] argument can also be made when looking at how Judas eventually submits to his oppressor. He arises from the pit as a heroic-type figure and it seems the reins of authority Elene exercises only do good in the end. It is contended that this justifies the authority of royalty in Cynewulf’s time.<ref>See Klein 2006</ref>
In terms of symbolism, the good-bad dichotomy, which is prevalent in Old English verse, finds itself in the oppositions of light and dark imagery in the poem. For instance, it is observed in the poem that Judas spends seven nights in a pit, and the 'darkness' can be seen to convey his obstinacy in refusing to see the 'light' of Christianity.<ref>See Greenfield 1965, p.114 and Klein 2006</ref>
Along with [[alliteration]], which is a key part to all Old English poetry, there are also places in the poem where Cynewulf applies rhyme in order to emphasize certain words, such as in the battle scene (50-55a): <poem> ''Ridon ymb rofne, ðonne rand '''dynede''', camp wudu '''clynede''', cyning ðreate for, herge to hilde. Hrefen uppe gol, wan ond wælfel. Werod wæs on tyhte. '''Hleopon''' hornboran, '''hreopan''' frican, mearh moldan træd.'' </poem>
''('They rode about the famous one; then the shield dinned, the battle-tarp clanged, the king advanced with a troop, a battalion to the battle. The raven yelled from above, dark and greedy for carrion. The troop was on the march. The horn-bearers ran, the heralds called out, the horse trod the earth''),<!-- (Zacher 354) --> In this example, the rhymes emphasize the din of voices and the crash of weapons,<!-- (Zacher 354) --> which builds excitement throughout the battle scene.

{{Use Australian English|date=July 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{italic title}} '''''The Encyclopaedia of Aboriginal Australia: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander history, society and culture''''',<ref name=isbn>Paper Set {{ISBN|0-85575-234-3}} Windows {{ISBN|0-85575-261-0}} Macintosh {{ISBN|0-85575-278-5}}</ref> edited by [[David Horton (Australia)|David Horton]], is an [[encyclopedia|encyclopaedia]] published by the "Aboriginal Studies Press" at the [[Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies]] (AIATSIS) in 1994 and available in two volumes or on [[CD-ROM]] covering all aspects of [[Indigenous Australians]] lives and world (such as biography, history, art, language, sport, education, archaeology, literature, land ownership, social organisation, health, music, law, technology, media, economy, politics, food and religion). There are 2000 entries and 1000 photographs, with the CD-ROM having 250 sound items and 40 videos.
An Indigenous language map was produced in 1996. It consists of names and regions used in the encyclopaedia of Aboriginal Australia. The map also shows some of the language groups in Australia with a more complete list on the reverse.<ref>Horton, David. Aboriginal Australia [map]. Canberra : AIATSIS, 1996.</ref>
==Contributors== Over 200 contributors wrote articles for the encyclopaedia. Many of them are Indigenous writers, activists or scholars. In an unusual decision, the editor has chosen to mention white people in the encyclopaedia only if they have some impact on Aboriginal society.<ref>Read, Peter. For the record. In: Australian book review. No. 165, Oct 1994, p. 29-30.</ref>
==Reviews==
The CD-ROM was made available after the launch of the book version in 1994. It was criticized for user-unfriendliness due to the lack of hypertext links. Important details, such as the passing of the ''[[Native Title Act 1993]]'', were missing from the CD-FOM, as of 1995.<ref>Nash, David and Keefe, Kevin. Encyclopaedia of Aboriginal Australia CDROM. In: Aboriginal history. Vol. 19, no. 1-2, 1995, p. 206-209</ref>
==Awards== The Encyclopaedia of Aboriginal Australia has received Awards: *''The Australian'' Award for Excellence in Educational Publishing *[[Western Australian Premier's Book Awards|WA Premier's Literary Award]]<ref>{{Cite web | title = Western Australian Premier's Book Awards - Historical & Critical Category Winners | accessdate = 2008-10-06 | date = 2006-10-06 | url = http://www.slwa.wa.gov.au/pbkhist.html |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080721211355/http://slwa.wa.gov.au/pbkhist.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-07-21}}</ref> *AIMMIA Award for Best Multimedia Title *CACS Award for ‘An Outstanding Contribution to Australian Culture 1994’ *[[New South Wales Premier's Literary Awards#Book of the Year|NSW Premier's Literary Award 1995 "Book of the Year"]]<ref>{{Cite journal |issn=0312-2417 |issue=44 |last=Welfare |first=Sharon |title=Book review: Encyclopaedia of Aboriginal Australia: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander History, Society and Culture by D. Horton |journal=Australian Archeology |accessdate=2008-10-06 |date=June 1997 |url=http://www.australianarchaeologicalassociation.com.au/node/1710 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121033858/http://www.australianarchaeologicalassociation.com.au/node/1710 |archivedate=2008-11-21 |df= }}</ref>
David Horton was awarded the [[New South Wales Premier's Literary Awards#Special Award|NSW Premier's Literary Award 1995 "Special Award"]] for the Encyclopaedia.

{{Esperanto sidebar |expanded=Culture}}
An '''Esperanto club''' ({{lang-eo|Esperanto-klubo}}) is a [[Club (organization)|club]] of [[Esperanto]] speakers, or [[Esperantist]]s. In contrast to national or international [[List of Esperanto organizations|Esperanto organizations]], an Esperanto club usually limits its activities only to a certain city or region. Esperanto clubs have been forming the backbone of the [[Esperanto movement]] since the beginning of the movement, although recently the situation is starting to change due to the possibility of immediate and first-hand communication that is provided by the [[Internet]].
The first Esperanto club was founded in [[Nuremberg]] on 18 February 1885, before Esperanto was published (1887) – originally it was a group of supporters of [[Volapük]], who in 1888 unanimously converted to Esperanto, under the influence of [[Leopold Einstein]]. The Nuremberg club was also the first to start publishing an [[List of Esperanto magazines|Esperanto magazine]], ''[[La Esperantisto]]''.
== Characteristics == Esperanto clubs may differ in a variety of ways: * Existence of a permanent meeting place; * Regularity and variety of activities; * Solid member base (and collection of membership fees); * Specialization in a certain level of Esperanto knowledge; * Specific interest in a topic behind Esperanto itself (e.g. Esperanto [[teacher]]s club, [[student]]s club, club of Esperanto-speaking [[paramedic]]s, club linked to a science center etc.); * Relation to a national Esperanto organization (usually the local branch of the [[Universal Esperanto Association]]); * Regular organization of Esperanto language courses.
=== List of first Esperanto clubs === Following is a list of Esperanto clubs founded between 1887 and 1895, i.e. during the first nine years of Esperanto's existence (names of the founders are given in brackets):<ref>Zakrzweski, Adam: ''Historio de Esperanto''. 1913, 144 pp.</ref>
* 1888 ** [[Nuremberg]] (Christian Schmidt) * 1889 ** [[Moscow]] ** [[Sofia]] (Bogdanov) * 1890 ** [[Gelsenkirchen|Schalke]] (Trompeter) ** [[Ivanovo|Ivanovo-Voznesensk]] ([[Antoni Grabowski]]) * 1891 ** [[Munich]] - "Societo E-isto-ja" = Internacia Klubo de Korespondado (L. E. Meyer of Nuremberg) ** [[Uppsala]] (S. Lundström) ** [[Murom]] (W. Brzozowski) ** [[Freiburg im Breisgau]] (dr. Haas) ** [[Saint Petersburg]] (Art. Florell) * 1892 ** [[Málaga]] ** [[Gothenburg]] (G. Backman) ** [[Osterby, Rendsburg-Eckernförde|Osterby]] (Ossian Holmquist) ** [[Erlangen]] (Fr. v. Brtesen) ** [[Schweinfurt]] (P. Kramer, Kirschner, Brand) ** [[Vilnius]] (A. Naumann) * 1893 ** [[Warsaw]] (Al. Blumental, Rubin, J. Wasniewski) * 1894 ** [[Steneby]] (Lindgven) ** [[Odessa]] (Gernet, Borovko) ** [[Reims]]-Soissons (Huisson) ** [[Helsinki]] (W. Fagershom) * 1895 ** [[Vladimir, Russia|Vladimir]] (V. Solodiĥin)
However, at the end of 1904, only three of these clubs were still in existence: Uppsala, Saint Petersburg, and Odessa. Other clubs often did not survive more than a year, as it was the case of the group in Reims, which was formed by young students of the local [[lyceum]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Fendika | image = Mélaku Belay & Zenash Tsegay.jpg | image_size = | landscape = yes | alt = | caption = Fendika members Melaku Belay and Zenash Tsegaye in 2009 | background = group_or_band | alias = Fendika Azmati Bet | origin = [[Addis Ababa]], [[Ethiopia]] | genre = [[Music of Ethiopia|Ethiopian music]] | years_active = 2009–present | label = [[Terp Records]] | associated_acts = Ethiocolor Cultural Band
[[Debo Band]]
[[The Ex (band)|The Ex]] | website = | current_members = | former_members = | module = | module2 = | module3 = }} '''Fendika''' ([[Amharic]]: "Exult!"{{cite news |title=Meskel Holiday Party in Brooklyn, NY w/ Ethiopia’s Fendika Dance Group at Tadias Magazine |url=http://www.tadias.com/09/20/2018/meskel-holiday-party-in-brooklyn-ny-w-ethiopias-fendika-dance-group/ |accessdate=3 October 2018 |work=Tadias Magazine |date=September 20, 2018}})is an [[Music of Ethiopia|Ethiopian music]] group based in [[Addis Ababa]]. Led by dancer/choreographer Melaku Belay, they operate a venue, tour, record, and perform under the name Fendika. ==History== [[File:The Ex and Melaku Belay.jpg|thumb|left|Melaku Belay onstage with [[The Ex (band)|The Ex]] in 2008]] Born in 1980 in Ethiopia, Melaku Belay lived as an orphan on the streets of Addis Ababa.{{cite news|last1=Unthank|first1=Rachel|title=Folk: Ethiopia|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/folk/2010/02/ethiopia-by-rachel-unthank-par-1.html#more|accessdate=13 December 2016|agency=BBC|date=24 February 2010}} As a child Belay earned a living shining shoes{{cite news |last1=Niederndorfer |first1=Florian |title=Ein Jazzclub steht dem Plan im Weg |url=https://www.pressreader.com/austria/der-standard/20180801/281616716175901 |accessdate=4 October 2018 |work=Der Standard |date=August 1, 2018 |language=German}} and taught himself to dance through participation in folk traditions and religious festivals.{{cite web|title=Fendika: Biography|url=https://www.kennedy-center.org/Artist/B75269|website=Kennedy Center|accessdate=13 December 2016}} He worked for seven years as a dancer for tips in Addis Ababa's Kazanchis neighborhood at a local ''azmari bet''—a tavern that hosts [[azmari]] story-songsters who accompany themselves on the [[masenko]] (a one-stringed [[violin]]) or [[krar]] (a type of [[lyre]]).{{cite web|last1=Halfpenny|first1=Eric|last2=Grame|first2=Theodore C|title=azmari: Ethiopian bard|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/azmari/article-websites|website=Encyclopædia Britannica|accessdate=21 December 2016}} Each night after work, the young Melaku slept under the bar and eventually saved enough money to buy the club, Fendika Azmari Bet, from its owners.{{cite news|last1=Doyle|first1=Rachel B.|title=In Ethiopia’s Capital, a Resurgent Jazz Scene|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/16/travel/in-ethiopias-capital-a-resurgent-jazz-scene.html?_r=0|accessdate=13 December 2016|work=The New York Times|date=13 November 2014}} When not working at the azmari bet, Melaku traveled extensively through [[Ethiopia]], [[Eritrea]], [[Somalia]], and [[South Sudan]] to learn as many dances as he could from more than 80 tribes around the [[Horn of Africa]],{{cite web|last1=Forster|first1=Siegfried|title=L’art et l’audace des " Regards sur l’Ethiopie " – RFI|url=http://www.rfi.fr/afrique/20100722-art-audace-regards-ethiopie|website=RFI Afrique|accessdate=14 December 2016|language=fr-FR|date=22 July 2010}} including the traditions of [[Gurage]], [[Welayta people#Wolayta music|Wolaita]], [[Tigrayans#Language and culture|Tigray]], [[Wollo]], [[Konso]], [[Gonder]], and [[Gojam]],{{cite web|title=Fendika|url=http://earthbeat.nl/fendika/|website=Earth Beat|accessdate=13 December 2016}} as well as dances from Somali and Afar regions.{{cite news |title=Melaku Belay & Fendika |url=http://www.matatu.co/routes/melaku-belay-fendika |accessdate=3 October 2018 |work=MATATU: Nomadic Cinema}} Melaku also became a nationally celebrated artist in ''[[eskesta]]'', a shoulder dance style whose movements share roots with [[hip hop]]'s traditions of [[locking (dance)|locking]] and [[popping]].{{cite news|title=Fendika|url=http://www.newyorker.com/goings-on-about-town/dance/fendika|accessdate=13 December 2016|work=The New Yorker}} With Ethiopia's capital city being a nexus of culture, music, and dance from other nations, Melaku incorporated these into his repertoire as well, gradually assembling a 13-piece ensemble called the Ethiocolor Cultural Band.{{cite web|title=Ethiocolor releases debut album|url=http://www.addiszefen.com/news/ethiocolor-releases-debut-album/|website=Addis Zefen|accessdate=14 December 2016|date=25 September 2014}} Combining tribal dances and folk instruments with jazz, rock, theater and elaborate costumes.{{cite web|title=Birabiro by Fendika|url=http://exmailorder.nl/shop/birabiro-lp|website=exmailorder.nl|publisher=The Ex|accessdate=13 December 2016}} The group became a staple at Fendika, rooted in the azmari tradition but with amplified versions of its instruments.{{cite web|title=Selam Sounds new Release: Ethiocolor|url=http://selam.se/eng/news/selam-sounds-new-release-ethiocolor|website=Selam|accessdate=14 December 2016|date=20 October 2014}} In 2009 Melaku assembled a smaller group out of the larger Ethiocolor ensemble, featuring three musicians, two dancers, and one singer. With a more portable acoustic sound and azmari folk aesthetic, the group named themselves Fendika in tribute to the establishment from which they originated.{{cite web|title=Fendika|url=http://www.cadenzaartists.com/fendika.html|website=Cadenza Artists|accessdate=13 December 2016}} [[File:Fendika and Debo in Philly 2010.jpg |thumb|300px|Fendika performing with [[Debo Band]] in 2010]] Through the Fendika venue's hosting touring artists from all over the world, the ensemble has established an international network enabling them to travel and collaborate with musicians from around the globe. They have toured the United States and eastern Africa with Boston-area [[Ethiojazz]] orchestra [[Debo Band]], and in 2010 the two groups released a joint live recording from a concert given at the [[Sauti za Busara]] African music festival in [[Zanzibar]].{{cite web|last1=Man|first1=Hog Eye|title=Interview: Debo Band|url=http://www.tinymixtapes.com/features/danny-mekonnen-of-debo-band|website=Tiny Mix Tapes|accessdate=16 December 2016|date=20 June 2012}} Fendika has also toured throughout Europe with Dutch [[post-punk]] band [[The Ex (band)|The Ex]] and released records through the band's label. In 2018 Fendika toured Scandinavia in collaboration with Paal Nilssen-Love’s free jazz orchestra Large Unit before embarking on their first U.S. solo tour, performing as headliners to Ethiopia Fest Chicago{{cite news |last1=Meyer |first1=Bill |title=Fearless song and dance troupe Fendika headlines Ethiopia Fest Chicago 2018 |url=https://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/fearless-song-and-dance-troupe-headlines-ethiopia-fest-chicago-2018/Content?oid=57441770 |accessdate=3 October 2018 |work=Chicago Reader |date=September 8, 2018 |language=en}} and Boston's Global Music Fest.{{cite web |title=Global Music Festival |url=http://www.bu.edu/gmf/ |website=www.bu.edu |publisher=Boston University |accessdate=3 October 2018 |language=en}} In their home city of Addis Ababa, Fendika have collaborated with many of their nation's most well-known musicians, including singer [[Mahmoud Ahmed]], [[begena]] player [[Alemu Aga]], and [[saxophone|saxophonist]] [[Getatchew Mekuria]].{{cite web|last1=Aymar|first1=Patrick|title=Melaku Belay|url=http://www.melakubelay.com/melaku|website=www.melakubelay.com|accessdate=13 December 2016}} ==Educational work== [[File:Fendika at PhilaMOCA.jpg|thumb|Fendika musicians at PhilaMOCA in 2018.]] Fendika often leads workshops in traditional Ethiopian music and dance. The group also supports a school for migrant children which aims to prevent youth homelessness and child labor by providing cultural education for these children and their families. At the azmadi bet, Belay supports a dozen young azmadis with room and board plus stipends to support their work. Fendika has also collaborated with members of [[The Ex (band)|The Ex]], [[Instant Composers Pool]], and others to bring electronic, punk, and improvised music education to Ethiopia.{{cite web|title=The Ex: History: 2008|url=http://www.theex.nl/history.html#y2008|website=The Ex|accessdate=13 December 2016}} ==Awards and tributes== In 2011 Melaku Belay won the Alliance Ethio-Francaise award for dance excellence and in 2015 was named Chevalier dans l’Ordre des Arts et des Lettres by the [[French Ministry of Culture]]. In 2011 Los Angeles rock group the [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]] released the song "Ethiopia" for their album ''[[I'm with You (album)|I'm with You]]'' based on band members' time spent at Fendika.{{cite news |last1=Aguillo |first1=Carlos |title=Clapping, dancing the night away at Fendika – AddisZefen |url=https://www.addiszefen.com/clapping-dancing-the-night-away-at-fendika/ |work=Addis Zefen |date=May 14, 2013}} While visiting Ethiopia with guitarist [[Josh Klinghoffer]], Peppers' bass player [[Flea (musician)|Flea]] had called up Melaku and asked to play at the venue.{{cite news |last1=Ellingsen |first1=Eric |title=“The Rehearsal: Poetry-Jazz in Addis Ababa,” by Eric Ellingsen |url=https://www.worldliteraturetoday.org/2018/september/rehearsal-poetry-jazz-addis-ababa-eric-ellingsen |work=World Literature Today |date=8 August 2018 |language=en}} Inspired by their experience at Fendika, the musicians returned home and penned the song.{{cite news |last1=Bakker |first1=Stephanie |title=Addis Abeba is het bruisende hart van Afrika |url=https://www.trouw.nl/samenleving/addis-abeba-is-het-bruisende-hart-van-afrika~a32130ac/ |accessdate=4 October 2018 |work=Trouw |date=May 23, 2018 |language=nl-NL}} ==Members== Fendika and Ethicolor perform, tour, and record in different configurations with ensembles that vary from 5 to 20 members at any given time.{{cite web|last1=Samuel|first1=Rahel|title=Ethiocolor Releases Debut Album {{!}} Ethiosports|url=http://www.ethiosports.com/2014/10/01/ethiocolor-releases-debut-album/|website=Ethiosports|accessdate=7 January 2017|date=1 October 2014}}{{cite book|last1=Beley|first1=Melaku|title=Melaku's Fendika: Volume 1|date=2016|publisher=Fendika|location=Addis Ababa|page=Back cover|format=Compact disc}} {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} ;Dance * Melaku Belay * Zinash Tsegaye * Frehiwot * Dagim ;Vocals * Nardos Tesfaw * Selamnesh Zemene * Belaynesh Bezabeh * Tesfaye Taye * Gashaw Abateneh * Hawa ;Krar * Fassika Hailu * Anteneh Teklemariam (bass krar) {{col-break}} ;Masenko * Gizachew Teklemariam * Endres Hassen * Asrat Bosena * Hargos Takele ;Kebero * Mesay Abebaye * Misale Legesse * Asrat Ayalew ;Flute * Yohannes Aferworq ;Songwriting * Tamru Neguse {{col-end}} ==Discography== ;Albums * ''Addis Tradition'' CD (2013){{cite news|title=Fendika with Joshua Abrams, Tim Daisy, Ben LaMar Gay, Macie Stewart and Mars Williams|url=http://www.constellation-chicago.com/event/1286653-fendika-fendika-joshua-chicago/|accessdate=7 January 2017|work=www.constellation-chicago.com|agency=Constellation|date=19 September 2016}}{{cite web|last1=Romeero|first1=Angel|title=Interview with Melaku Belay of Ethiopian Band Fendika {{!}} World Music Central.org|url=http://worldmusiccentral.org/2015/12/29/interview-with-melaku-belay-of-ethiopian-band-fendika/|website=World Music Central|accessdate=7 January 2017|date=29 December 2015}} * [[Hunter S. Thompson]] | cinematography = Andre Fontanelle | editing = Jayne Rodericks |music=Carvin Knowles | studio = Mudflap Films
[[Rainstorm Entertainment]] | distributor = [[THINKFilm]] | released = {{Film date|2005|11|07}} | runtime = 93 minutes | country = United States | language = American English }} '''''Fuck''''' is a 2005 American documentary film by director [[Steve Anderson (director)|Steve Anderson]] about the word "[[fuck]]". The film argues that the word is an integral part of societal discussions about [[freedom of speech]] and [[censorship]]. It examines the term from perspectives which include art, linguistics, society and comedy, and begins with a segment from the 1965 propaganda film ''[[Perversion for Profit]]''. Scholars and celebrities analyze perceptions of the word from differing perspectives. Journalist [[Sam Donaldson]] talks about the versatility of the word, and comedian [[Billy Connolly]] states it can be understood despite one's language or location. Musician [[Alanis Morissette]] comments that the word contains power because of its taboo nature. The film features the last recorded interview of author [[Hunter S. Thompson]] before his suicide. Scholars, including linguist [[Reinhold Aman]], journalism analyst [[David Shaw (writer)|David Shaw]] and ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' editor [[Jesse Sheidlower]], explain the history and evolution of the word. Language professor [[Geoffrey Nunberg]] observes that the word's treatment by society reflects changes in our culture during the 20th century. Anderson was exposed to public conceptions surrounding the word "fuck" by comedian [[George Carlin]]'s monologue "[[Seven dirty words|Seven Words You Can Never Say on Television]]". He named the film ''Fuck'' despite anticipating problems with marketing. Animator [[Bill Plympton]] provided sequences illustrating key concepts in the film. The documentary was first shown at the [[AFI Film Festival]] on November 7, 2005, at [[ArcLight Hollywood]] in [[Hollywood]]. ''Fuck'''s reviews were generally mixed. Film critic [[A. O. Scott]] called the documentary a battle between advocates of morality and supporters of freedom of expression. ''[[The Washington Post]]'' and the New York ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'' criticized its length and other reviewers disliked its repetitiveness – the word "fuck" is used 857 times in the film. In his 2009 book ''[[Fuck: Word Taboo and Protecting Our First Amendment Liberties]]'', law professor [[Christopher M. Fairman]] called the movie "the most important film using 'fuck'". The [[American Film Institute]] said, "Ultimately, ''Fuck'' is a movie about free speech ... Freedom of expression must extend to words that offend. Love it or hate it, fuck is here to stay." ==Content summary== [[File:Perversion-for-Profit-putnam.jpg|thumb|left|The documentary begins with a segment from the 1965 propaganda film ''Perversion for Profit''.|alt=A still shot from the 1965 film ''Perversion for Profit'' showing a man in a suit holding a placard. The placard features a cartoonish image of a leering man and the phrase "It's a two billion dollar business"]] ''Fuck'' begins with a segment from the 1965 propaganda film ''[[Perversion for Profit]]'',{{cite news|work=Culture Wars|url=http://www.culturewars.org.uk/index.php/site/article/a_multifunctional_gem/|accessdate=April 20, 2013|first=Sam|last=Peczek|title=A multifunctional gem: Fuck (2005), directed by Steve Anderson|date=March 27, 2009|publisher=Institute of Ideas|location=London}} followed by a clip from ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' which states that the word can be used as a "sentence enhancer". The documentary includes commentary from film and television writers [[Kevin Smith]] and [[Steven Bochco]]; comedians [[Janeane Garofalo]], [[Bill Maher]], [[Drew Carey]] and [[Billy Connolly]]; musicians [[Chuck D]], [[Alanis Morissette]] and [[Ice T]]; political commentators [[Alan Keyes]] and [[Pat Boone]]; and journalists [[Michael Medved]] and [[Judith Martin]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/698cbd2e-f85a-11dd-aae8-000077b07658.html|work=[[Financial Times]]|accessdate=April 17, 2013|first=Karl|last=French|title=The slow road to revelation|date=February 11, 2009}} The word "fuck" is used 857 times during the film.{{cite news|first=Zoe|last=Mak|title= Director gives the F-word an airing|url=http://www.scmp.com/article/588263/director-gives-f-word-airing|accessdate=April 22, 2013|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|location=Hong Kong|date=April 9, 2007|page=3; Section: News|quote= But in a movie now being shown in Hong Kong, it is heard no fewer than 857 times. It is 'the F-word', and it is still so controversial that on posters for the documentary of the same name, the 'u' has been replaced by an asterisk.}} [[File:Billy Connolly in Fuck film.jpg|thumb|[[Billy Connolly]] reflects in the film on the versatility of the word and its ability to communicate across languages.|alt=Billy Connolly laughing]] Scholarly analysis is provided by ''[[Maledicta]]'' publisher [[Reinhold Aman]], journalism analyst [[David Shaw (writer)|David Shaw]]{{cite news|first=A. O.|last=Scott|authorlink=A. O. Scott|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2006/11/10/movies/10ffff.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=No Way to Put This Delicately|date=November 10, 2006|accessdate=April 22, 2013|page=E12 }} and ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' editor [[Jesse Sheidlower]].{{cite news|first=Charles|last=Britton|title=Unrated documentary fails to spell out its case for 'The F-Word'|date=November 10, 2006|work=[[Daily Breeze]]|location=Torrance, California|page=R14}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bigpicturebigsound.com/fuck-925.shtml|work=Big Picture Big Sound|title=Fuck Movie Review by Joe Lozito|first=Joe|last=Lozito|date=November 9, 2006|accessdate=April 25, 2013}} Language professor [[Geoffrey Nunberg]] says, "You could think of that [word] as standing in for most of the changes that happened in the 20th century, at least many of the important ones".{{cite news|title=Documentary 'F*ck' is less than word pefect|work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=November 17, 2006|first=Bill |last=Stamets |page=NC31}} The film next features author [[Hunter S. Thompson]] in his final documented interview. ''Fuck'' later includes archival footage of comedians [[Lenny Bruce]] and [[George Carlin]], and analysis of the word's use in popular culture, from ''[[MASH (film)|MASH]]'' (1970) to ''[[Scarface (1983 film)|Scarface]]'' (1983) and ''[[Clerks]]'' (1994). Carlin's 1972 monologue "[[Seven dirty words|Seven Words You Can Never Say on Television]]" is excerpted in the film. Journalist [[Sam Donaldson]] comments on the versatility of "fuck": "It's one of those all-purpose words." Bill Maher comments, "It's the ultimate bad word", observing that thanks to Lenny Bruce, [[comedy club]]s have become "the freest free-speech zone" in the United States. Connolly states that "fuck" "sounds exactly like what it is", noting that the emotional impact of saying "fuck off" cannot be translated. He says that if you are in [[Lhasa Gonggar Airport|Lhasa airport]] and someone is fiddling with your luggage, yelling "fuck off" will effectively communicate that they should stop and leave.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/feb/12/documentary|title=Film & Music: Film reviews: Fuck: 2/5: Director: Steve Anderson: 93 mins, no cert|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Peter |last=Bradshaw|date=February 13, 2009|page=9; Section: Guardian Film and Music Pages}} Morissette says, "The f-word is special. Everybody uses the word 'breakfast', but not everyone feels comfortable using the word 'fuck' so there's an extra power behind it."{{cite news|first=Rowan|last=Walker|work=[[The Observer]]|title=First Person: Is this an f-word too far?: A new documentary about a certain four-letter epithet has got America talking (so long as they don't use that word). Rowan Walker asks if it deserves four stars|page=28; Section: Observer Focus Pages|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2006/nov/19/film.filmnews|date=November 18, 2006|accessdate=April 22, 2013 }} Boone argues for less use of the word, saying that he uses his surname instead.{{cite news|first=Dave|last=White|work=[[Movies.com]]|title=F*ck Review|url=http://www.movies.com/movie-reviews/fck-review/dave-white/m63820|accessdate=April 18, 2013|date=November 10, 2005}}{{cite news|title=Movies: Opened last week|first=Geoff |last=Pevere|date=December 7, 2006|work=[[Toronto Star]]|page=G14; Section: What's On}} Radio talk show host [[Dennis Prager]] says that it is acceptable for youths to hear the word on television and film, but not from their family members.{{cite news|first=Sam|last=Hatch|title=Culture Dogs- Sam Hatch's F*ck Review|work=[[WWUH]] |accessdate=April 25, 2013|year=2006|url=http://www.wwuh.org/program/culturedogs/Reviews/Sam%20Reviews/fck.htm}} In the film, opponents of the word "fuck" use an argument commonly known as "[[Think of the children]]".{{efn|"Think of the children" is a rhetorical device used by those who wish to cast youth as victims in order to win a political argument.{{cite book|pages=165–167|title=Community, Space and Online Censorship: Regulating Pornotopia|first=Scott |last=Beattie|year=2009|publisher=Ashgate|isbn=978-0-7546-7308-8}}}} ''Fuck'' observes that the original use of the word is unknown to scholars,{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/30/AR2006113000107.html|title=Cursing swear word's history|work=[[Northwest Herald]]|location=Crystal Lake, Illinois|date=December 7, 2006|quote=Among the revelations: The first use of the word in a mainstream movie was a mumbled curse in "M*A*S*H"; the word's origin remains mysterious, but it is definitely not a corruption of a medieval designation involving unlawful carnal knowledge. }} noting that its earliest written appearance was in the 1475 poem "[[Flen flyys]]". It was not, as is often claimed, originally an [[acronym]] for "For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge" or "Fornication Under Consent of the King".{{cite book|first=Darwin|last=Porter|author2=Danforth Prince|title=Blood Moon's Guide to Gay and Lesbian Film: Second Edition|publisher=Blood Moon Productions|year=2007|isbn=0-9748118-7-4}}{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/movies/article/FILM-CLIPS-Also-opening-today-2466613.php|accessdate=April 17, 2013|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|first=Mick|last=LaSalle|title=Film Clips / Also opening today|date=November 17, 2006}} The word has been used by authors including [[Robert Burns]], [[D. H. Lawrence]] (in his 1928 ''[[Lady Chatterley's Lover]]'') and [[James Joyce]].{{cite news|url=http://movies.tvguide.com/fk/review/283661|accessdate=April 18, 2013|work=[[TV Guide]]|first=Ken|last=Fox|title=F**k Review|year=2006}} The film explains that "fuck" established its current usage during the First and Second World Wars, and was used by General [[George S. Patton]] in a speech to his forces who were about to enter France.{{cite news|first=Rob|last=Nelson|work=[[The Village Voice]]|title='Fuck'|date=October 31, 2006|accessdate=April 18, 2013|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2006-10-31/film/fuck/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130630140833/http://www.villagevoice.com/2006-10-31/film/fuck/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=June 30, 2013}} ''Fuck'' states that the first use of the word in a large-studio film was in ''M*A*S*H'' (1970),{{cite news|work=[[Toronto Star]]|title=The day the f-word hit the screen|date=December 1, 2006 |page=D01; Section: Movies}} and it entered the ''Oxford English Dictionary'' in 1972. That year, the word was also recorded during the [[Apollo 16]] United States mission to [[Moon landing|land on the Moon]].{{cite news|url=http://www.currentfilm.com/dvdreviews8/f-ckdvd.html|accessdate=April 25, 2013|title=DVD Review: F-ck|work=Current Film|year=2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130826233221/http://www.currentfilm.com/dvdreviews8/f-ckdvd.html|archivedate=August 26, 2013|df=mdy-all}} The film includes a segment from the 1987 film ''[[Planes, Trains and Automobiles]]'' with actor [[Steve Martin]], in which "fuck" is repeated for comedic effect. ''Fuck'' states that the most financially successful [[live action]] comedy film to date had the suggestive title of ''[[Meet the Fockers]]'' (2004). The director analyzes the uses and connotations of "fuck" and the feelings it evokes on several levels. Bruce is quoted as saying, "If you can't say 'fuck', you can't say 'fuck the government'". Steve Anderson argues that "fuck" is an integral part of societal discussions about [[freedom of speech]] and [[censorship]].{{cite news|first=Chelsea|last=Bain|work=[[Boston Herald]]|title=Movie Review: Flick doesn't mince words|date=December 8, 2006|page=E17}}{{cite news|first=Peter|last=Keough|work=[[The Boston Phoenix]]|title=Reviews: Fuck – Not for children|date=December 6, 2006|url=http://thephoenix.com/boston/Movies/29106-FUCK/|accessdate=April 17, 2013}}{{cite news|first=Sally|last=Foster|work=[[Film Threat]]|title=Fuck|url=http://www.filmthreat.com/reviews/8770/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418000000/http://www.filmthreat.com/reviews/8770/|archivedate=April 18, 2012|accessdate=April 17, 2013|date=March 23, 2006}} ==Soundtrack== ''Fuck'' includes songs with similarly themed titles, including "[[Shut Up and Fuck]]" by American [[hard rock]] band [[Betty Blowtorch]], "Fucking Fucking Fuck" by Splatpattern and "[[I Love to Say Fuck]]" by American [[horror punk]] supergroup [[Murderdolls]]. Section: The Globe Review 7; film}} and became fascinated by the usage of the word "fuck".{{cite news|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100222003812/http://sandiegometro.archives.whsites.net/reel/index.php?reelID=987|archivedate=February 22, 2010|url=http://sandiegometro.archives.whsites.net/reel/index.php?reelID=987|accessdate=April 17, 2013|date=December 2006|title=The Reel Story: F*ck – History of a bad word|work=San Diego Metropolitan Magazine & Daily Business Report|first=Jean |last=Lowerison}} In an interview with the ''[[Democrat and Chronicle]]'', Anderson suggested he cursed a lot more than he used to after the film's production. He decided to research the film's topic due to the word's versatility and his interest in language as a writer. Early exposure by Anderson to public perception of the word "fuck" came from ''[[Class Clown]]'' by comedian George Carlin, which included his monologue "Seven Words You Can Never Say on Television".{{cite news|title='Naughty word' intrigues Pittsford grad|date=January 4, 2007|first=Jack|last=Garner|work=[[Democrat and Chronicle]]|location=Rochester, New York}}{{cite news|work=[[Tucson Citizen]]|first=Jack|last=Garner|title=Carlin's list a 'precursor' to new documentary|date=January 18, 2007}} The director explained in an interview that he was fascinated with the word "fuck" because of its different uses. He originally proposed the idea of a film about the word in jest, later realizing that the topic could fuel a documentary.{{cite news|first=Jay ([[CanWest News Service]])|last=Stone|work=[[National Post]]|date=November 28, 2006|title=Defusing The F-bomb: New Doc. Director tackles The Profundity Of Profanity|page=B3}} ''[[The Observer]]'' quoted him as saying that he was entertained by the word "fuck", and intrigued with the idea of examining how the word had been incorporated into popular culture. He wanted to analyze why some people were offended by its use and others enjoyed it, noting that the word sharpened debate about taboo language in society. Anderson explained to the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' the confusing, forbidden nature of the word "fuck" in the face of the increased pervasiveness of euphemisms for it. He commented on its taboo nature and demonstrated how it can be indirectly referred to, so youth understand the reference without using the word itself.{{cite news|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20040427&slug=cursing27|title=Flush that potty mouth with popular euphemisms|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|first=Lynn ([[Los Angeles Times]])|last=Smith|date=April 27, 2004|page=C1; Edition: Fourth; Section: Northwest Life}} In an interview with the ''[[South China Morning Post]]'', Anderson said that film directors should fight against censorship, because it can block their true message. The director told CanWest News Service that he hoped the documentary would provoke a wider discussion about freedom of speech, [[sexual slang]] and its media use. Anderson questioned whether the word should be used on ''[[NYPD Blue]]'', and how parents should discuss its use with their children. He emphasized that artists and filmmakers should be free to express their views without censorship, deferring to public opinion on the appropriateness of his documentary's title. Anderson stated in an interview with [[IndieWire]] that freedom of speech was not guaranteed, but a concept requiring discussion and monitoring so it is not lost. He classified the word "fuck" as being at the core of discussion about freedom of speech. He acknowledged that there are terms considered by society more vulgar than "fuck", but said that this particular word creates controversy and dialogue.{{cite news|date=November 9, 2006|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/indiewire_interview_steve_anderson_director_of_fuck2|accessdate=April 23, 2013|title=indieWIRE Interview: Steve Anderson, director of 'Fuck'|author=IndieWire staff|work=[[IndieWire]]|quote=From the very beginning we didn't know what we were going to call it. For the entire production it was known as "The Untitled F-Word Film." I always harbored the desire to eventually call it "Fuck" but as a producer as well as a director, you have to consider getting the film into theaters. People need to be able to see the film. In the end, after much discussion and many alternate titles, we decided to simply call if "Fuck." It was the honest thing to do.}} Anderson said that its title alone distinguished his documentary from others, in terms of promotional difficulty. During production, ''Fuck'' was known as ''The Untitled F-Word Film''. ==={{anchor|Title choice and marketing}}Title and marketing=== [[File:Fuck film interview grid.tif|thumb|Steve Anderson said that the title of his film was ''Fuck'', but he allowed marketing designs with an asterisk.|alt=Fuck with asterisk instead of letter U, with background of tiled images of interviewees from film]] In an interview about the film on his website, Anderson discussed problems he encountered in naming his film ''Fuck'' instead of a censored version of the word. Anderson always wanted to call it ''Fuck'', because it succinctly described the film's contents.{{efn|''Fuck'' is styled as ''FUCK'', ''F★CK'', or ''F*CK'' and alternatively referred to as ''Fuck: A Documentary'' and ''The F-Bomb: A Documentary''.{{cite news|url=http://dvd.netflix.com/Movie/The-F-Bomb-A-Documentary/70058003|accessdate=June 8, 2013|year=2013|work=[[Netflix]]|title=The F-Bomb: A Documentary}}{{cite news|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_f_bomb_a_documentary/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027150801/http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_f_bomb_a_documentary/|archivedate=October 27, 2013|accessdate=June 8, 2013|year=2013|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|title=The F-bomb: A Documentary}}}} There were inherent problems with this approach, including an inability to advertise the true title in mainstream media such as ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''Los Angeles Times'' (they used four asterisks instead), although the real title might be permitted in [[alternative newspaper]]s such as ''[[LA Weekly]]''. Anderson also anticipated problems displaying the film's title during film festivals on theatre [[Marquee (sign)|marquees]]. Anderson explained that although the title of his documentary was ''Fuck'', he allowed alternate designations using an asterisk. The film and content he controlled would refer to the title as ''Fuck'', including theatrical and DVD editions. He concluded that his struggle reflected the debate alluded to by the documentary, and this realization motivated him to stand firm on the film's title. Because the film is about how a taboo word can impact culture, it was important to keep ''Fuck'' as its title.{{cite news|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|title=Could Oscar be a four-letter word?|date=March 27, 2006|page=1; Section: The Globe Review}} ===Filming and distribution=== [[File:Word Man Pointing in Fuck film.jpg|thumb|left|The film uses animation by Bill Plympton to illustrate key concepts.|alt=Animated character in suit and hat pointing at sign reading Fuck with spectators observing seated in stands]] The film features animation by American graphic designer and cartoonist [[Bill Plympton]].{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/nov/05/entertainment/ca-sneakslist5|accessdate=April 25, 2013|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|title=It's looking pretty cool – Holiday Movie Sneaks – Wintry escapades, icy stares and cold-blooded killers are part of a flurry of year-end films.|date=November 5, 2006}} To illustrate key concepts, ''Fuck'' uses sound bites, music, video clips and archival film footage; Anderson combined excerpts from five television series and twenty-two films in the documentary. The interviews were cut so that different subjects appear to be talking to each other; the interviewees in question generally had opposite views on the subject.{{cite news|url=http://reelfilm.com/hot0600.htm#fuck|accessdate=April 18, 2013|title=The 13th Annual Hot Docs Film Festival: Fuck|first=David|last=Nusair|work=Reel Film Reviews|date=May 4, 2006}} The film was unrated by the [[Motion Picture Association of America]].{{cite news|title=Movie review: 'F**k'|date=November 16, 2006|url=http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/movies/11524686.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100222003851/http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/movies/11524686.html|archivedate=February 22, 2010|accessdate=April 17, 2013|first=Colin|last=Covert|work=[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis }}{{cite news|title=Capsule Reviews of Arriving Films|date=November 7, 2006|first=Christy |agency=Associated Press|last=Lemire}} [[Rainstorm Entertainment]] was confirmed in November 2003 to produce and finance the documentary, with production scheduled to begin in January 2004.{{cite news|title=Rainstorm swears by doc|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=November 10, 2003|page=27|first=Dana|last=Harris}} The film was completed in 2005 by Anderson's company, Mudflap Films, and produced by Rainstorm Entertainment co-founders Steven Kaplan and Gregg Daniel, and Bruce Leiserowitz, Jory Weitz and Richard Ardi. Financial assistance was provided by Bad Apple Films of [[Spokane, Washington]]. [[File:Hunter S. Thompson in Fuck film.jpg|thumb|The documentary featured the last interview with author [[Hunter S. Thompson]] before his suicide and honored Thompson's contributions to journalism.|alt=Hunter S. Thompson]] Thirty-five media commentators were interviewed for the film. Jory Weitz helped obtain interviews; he had cast Anderson's previous film, ''The Big Empty'', and had industry credibility as executive producer of ''[[Napoleon Dynamite]]''. Anderson said he intended to select interviewees with a variety of perspectives, conservative as well as liberal. He described how, as confirmations of interview subjects came in, he was surprised when Pat Boone was among the first to confirm his participation. Anderson had previously worked as a cameraman on a piece with Boone about eight years before starting work on ''Fuck''. After confirming Boone, Bill Maher and Janeane Garofalo on ''Fuck'', it became easier for Anderson to confirm other interviewees. The film included the final video interview with Hunter S. Thompson before his suicide, and Anderson dedicated it to Thompson for his contributions to journalism. Distribution rights to ''Fuck'' were obtained by [[THINKFilm]] in 2006.{{cite news|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20061207/news_lz1w07fword.html|title=What the bleep? Film is pretty darn good|first=David|last=Elliott|work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]|date=December 7, 2006|page=9; Night & Day; Section: Entertainment|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211040507/http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20061207/news_lz1w07fword.html|archivedate=December 11, 2013|df=mdy-all}} Movie chains did not use the film's title in their promotion, instead using references such as ''The Four-Letter Word Film''. Mark Urman, chief of the theatrical division of THINKFilm, told ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' that it was especially difficult (as an independent film distributor) to promote a film with a title media outlets did not wish to print. Urman told ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' that the intent of the production staff during promotion was a creative, original marketing campaign.{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2006/film/news/think-takes-daring-docu-1117940368/|first=Ian|last=Mohr|title=Think takes daring docu|date=March 27, 2006|page=2; Section: News|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|location=New York}} THINKFilm marketed the documentary as a comprehensive, humorous look at the dichotomy between the taboo nature and cultural universality of the word "fuck".{{cite news|title=Cannes Market Listings|date=May 15, 2006|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|page=64; Special Report 1: Special Supplement: VPLUS: Cannes 2006|author=Variety staff}} ==Reception== ===Release=== ''Fuck'' was shown for the first time on November 7, 2005, at the [[AFI Film Festival|American Film Institute Film Festival]]{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2005/film/news/launchpad-s-taking-off-1117931228/|title=Launchpad's taking off|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=October 19, 2005|first=Ian|last=Mohr|page=3; Section: News|location=New York}}{{cite news|url=http://www.afi.com/afifest/2005/daily/5b.aspx|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628064837/http://www.afi.com/afifest/2005/daily/5b.aspx|archivedate=June 28, 2011|accessdate=April 17, 2013|title=Director Steve Anderson Examines a Loaded Word|date=November 7, 2005|first=Peter|last=Martin|work=Live From the Fest: Daily News|publisher=[[American Film Institute]]}} at the ArcLight Hollywood on Sunset Boulevard in Hollywood, California.{{cite news|url=http://www.afi.com/afifest/2005/daily/1a.aspx|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628064911/http://www.afi.com/afifest/2005/daily/1a.aspx|archivedate=June 28, 2011|accessdate=April 20, 2013|title=Walk the Line Opening Night Gala Kicks Off AFI FEST 2005|work=Life from the Fest: Daily News|first=Brent|last=Simon|publisher=[[American Film Institute]]|date=November 3, 2005}} On March 10, 2006, interest increased after the opening night of the 20th [[South by Southwest Film Festival]] in [[Austin, Texas]].{{cite news|title=Buzz movies roll, then Austin rocks|first=Michael|last=Norman|date=March 14, 2006|work=[[The Plain Dealer]]|location=Cleveland, Ohio|page=E4}} At the 30th [[Cleveland International Film Festival]], it sold out two screenings (which were standing-room only events).{{cite news|title=Along Came a Spider ... and other high notes from the Cleveland Film Festival|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|first=Barry|last=Paris|page=E-1}} ''Fuck'' was featured on March 31 and April 2, 2006, at the [[Florida Film Festival]]. It was screened in April 2006 during the [[Philadelphia Film Festival]] at [[Prince Music Theater]] in [[Philadelphia]].{{cite news|url=http://articles.philly.com/2006-04-11/news/25395195_1_word-asterisk-wolf-parade|title=Obscene word now often seen and heard|date=April 11, 2006|first=Amy S. |last=Rosenberg|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|page=F01; Section: Features Magazine}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thewhitonline.com/Fbombblowsawayfilmfestival/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103042024/http://www.thewhitonline.com/Fbombblowsawayfilmfestival/|archivedate=November 3, 2014|accessdate=April 25, 2013|work=The Whit|title=F-bomb blows away film festival|date=April 13, 2006|publisher=[[Rowan University]]; www.thewhitonline.com|first=Jonathan|last=Guito|location=Glassboro, New Jersey}} It had its Washington, D.C. premiere in June 2006, and was shown on June 15 at the [[Nantucket Film Festival]].{{cite news|title=The Official Guide – To the Nantucket Film Festival – 11th Annual|date=June 14, 2006|first=Marli |last=Guzzetta|work=[[Nantucket Independent]]|page=25}} ''Fuck'' opened in Los Angeles on August 23, 2006 and in New York on November 10.{{cite news|accessdate=April 17, 2013|url=http://www.afi.com/members/catalog/DetailView.aspx?s=&Movie=63831|title=Movie Detail: Fuck|work=AFI Catalog of Feature Films|publisher=[[American Film Institute]]|year=2013}} It made its Canadian debut at the 2006 [[Hot Docs Canadian International Documentary Festival]],{{cite news|url=https://variety.com/2006/film/news/railroad-to-kick-off-hot-docs-fest-1117940513/|first=Tamsen|last=Tillson|title='Railroad' to kick off Hot Docs fest|date=March 29, 2006|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|page=11; Section: News}} and began regular showings at the [[Bloor Cinema]] on December 1.{{cite news|first=Geoff |last=Pevere|work=[[Toronto Star]]|title=It's one great Boone-ing movie|page=D04; Section: Movies|date=December 1, 2006}} The documentary began screening at the Century Centre Cinema in Chicago on November 17, 2006.{{cite news|title=Queen mother of curses gets its due, sort of|work=Daily Herald|location=Arlington Heights, Illinois|date=November 17, 2006|first=Dann |last=Gire|page=49}} ''Fuck'' had two screenings in April 2007 during the [[Hong Kong International Film Festival]] in [[Tsim Sha Tsui]]. According to a 2011 interview with Anderson in the ''[[Santa Barbara Independent]]'', the documentary was shown in about 100 film festivals worldwide and was screened in about 65 cities during its theatrical release. ===Critical response=== [[File:Christopher Fairman.jpg|thumb|upright|In his book ''[[Fuck: Word Taboo and Protecting Our First Amendment Liberties]]'', [[Christopher M. Fairman]] of the [[Moritz College of Law]] at [[Ohio State University]] called the documentary "the most important film using 'fuck'".{{cite book|first=Christopher M.|last=Fairman|authorlink=Christopher M. Fairman|title=[[Fuck: Word Taboo and Protecting Our First Amendment Liberties]] |pages=19–20|publisher=Sphinx Publishing|year=2009|isbn=1-57248-711-9}}|alt=Christopher Fairman]] ''Fuck'' received mixed reviews. The [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported a 56% approval rating with an average rating of 5.8/10 based on 72 reviews. The website's consensus reads, "A documentary that sets out to explore a lingual taboo but can't escape its own naughty posturing."{{cite news|title=Fuck (F*ck) (2005)|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/fuck/|publisher=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=8 February 2014 }} At [[Metacritic]], which assigns a weighted-mean rating from 0–100 based on reviews by film critics, the film has a rating score of 58 based on 23 reviews (a mixed, or average, film).{{cite news |title=Fuck Reviews – Metacritic |work=[[Metacritic]]|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/fuck|accessdate=April 17, 2013|year=2013}} The American Film Institute wrote, "Ultimately, ''Fuck'' is a movie about free speech ... Freedom of expression must extend to words that offend. Love it or hate it, fuck is here to stay".{{cite news|first=Rose|last=Vincelli|url=http://www.afi.com/silverdocs/2006/films/fuck.aspx|accessdate=April 17, 2013|title=Fuck|work=Silverdocs 2006 Film Guide|publisher=[[American Film Institute]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070619174612/http://www.afi.com/silverdocs/2006/films/FUCK.aspx|archivedate=June 19, 2007}} Jack Garner of the ''Democrat and Chronicle'' gave the film a rating of 8 out of 10, concluding that he was pleasantly surprised at the documentary's entertainment value. He described it as educational, despite ''Fuck''{{'}}s repetitive use of the word.{{cite news|first=Jack|last=Garner|title='F---: The Documentary'|work=[[Democrat and Chronicle]]|date=January 5, 2007|accessdate=April 17, 2013|url=http://www.democratandchronicle.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070105/LIVING0107/701050363/1065/ENT04}} In ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' Wesley Morris commented that the director's flippant style was beneficial, enabling him to make serious educational points to the audience.{{cite news|first=Wesley|last=Morris|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2006/12/08/presenting_the_history_of_a_four_letter_word/|accessdate=April 17, 2013|title=Movie Review: Presenting the history of a four-letter word|date=December 8, 2006}} Sally Foster of ''[[Film Threat]]'' said that the crux of the film was the debate about freedom of speech, and that the film was funny and thought-provoking. [[A. O. Scott]] wrote in ''The New York Times'': "Mr. Anderson's movie is staged as a talking-head culture-war skirmish between embattled upholders of propriety (or repression, if you prefer) and proponents of free expression (or filth), but its real lesson is that the two sides depend upon each other. Or rather, that the continued vitality of the word—its unique ability to convey emphasis, relieve stress, shock grown-ups and function as adverb, noun, verb, intensifier and what linguists call 'infix'—rests on its ability to mark an edge between the permissible and the profane". In the ''[[Chicago Reader]]'', Jonathan Rosenbaum wrote that the documentary was an amusing film and an educational commentary on the word.{{cite news|first=Jonathan|last=Rosenbaum|work=[[Chicago Reader]]|url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/fuck/Film?oid=1069019|accessdate=April 22, 2013|title=Fuck|date=November 17, 2006}} According to Glenn Garvin of ''[[The Miami Herald]]'', the film was an expansive merging of perspectives from politics, history and culture. In a review for ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' Marjorie Baumgarten gave the film a rating of 4.5 out of five stars, concluding that it helped unravel myths surrounding the word and describing it as captivating and educational.{{cite news|first=Marjorie|last=Baumgarten|work=[[The Austin Chronicle]]|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/calendar/film/2006-12-01/423455/|accessdate=April 17, 2013|title=F*ck|date=December 1, 2006}} Steve Schneider reviewed the film for the ''[[Orlando Weekly]]'', comparing it to an academic thesis despite its repeated use of [[off-color humor]].{{cite news|first=Steve|last=Schneider|work=[[Orlando Weekly]]|title=Closing Frames: What to watch for in the final weekend of the Florida Film Festival|date=March 30, 2006|accessdate=April 17, 2013|url=http://www2.orlandoweekly.com/film/story.asp?id=10590}} Noel Murray of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the film a grade of B-minus, stating that ''Fuck'' succeeded where [[Kirby Dick]]'s ''[[This Film Is Not Yet Rated]]'' did not, by providing viewpoints from multiple perspectives.{{cite news|first=Noel|last=Murray|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/fuck,3712/|accessdate=April 17, 2013|title=Fuck – Film – Movie Review|date=November 9, 2006|quote=On the other side: ... Pat Boone, Alan Keyes, and Dennis Prager, who find myriad ways of saying 'Think of the children.'}} Karl French wrote in a review for the ''[[Financial Times]]'' that the documentary was unique and reasonably entertaining. Moira MacDonald asked, in a review for ''[[The Seattle Times]]'', if viewers could embrace the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution]] and still be leery of the word's omnipresence in society.{{cite news|first=Moira|last=MacDonald|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?slug=thatmovie01&date=20061201|accessdate=April 17, 2013|title=Movie Review: F***": Film about F-bomb's power fails to fully detonate|date=December 1, 2006}} [[Mick LaSalle]] wrote in the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' that the commentators seemed monotonous and formulaic in debating freedom of speech, and criticized the film's repetition of the word "fuck". Peter Keough reviewed the film for the ''[[The Phoenix (newspaper)|Boston Phoenix]]''; giving it a rating of two out of four stars, he also said that the repeated use of "fuck" grew tiresome. In a critical review for ''The Observer'' Philip French wrote that the film had low comedic value, calling it arrogant, puerile and tedious.{{cite news|first=Philip|last=French|work=[[The Observer]]|title=Film Review: Fuck|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/feb/14/documentary|accessdate=April 17, 2013|date=February 14, 2009}} Peter Bradshaw of ''[[The Guardian]]'' gave the film two out of five stars, criticizing its lack of originality.{{cite news|first=Peter|last=Bradshaw|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=February 12, 2009|title=Film Review: Fuck|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/feb/12/documentary|accessdate=April 17, 2013}} In a review for ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' magazine, David Parkinson also gave the film a rating of two out of five stars and was frustrated that arguments by the director seemed guarded;{{cite news|first=David|last=Parkinson|work=[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]|title=Empire's Fuck Movie Review|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=136047|accessdate=April 17, 2013|year=2009}} he said that the film's scope was not comedic, amusing or provoking enough. In ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out London]]'' David Jenkins gave the film one star out of six, writing that it lacked depth on the issues of linguistics, media, and censorship.{{cite news|first=David|last=Jenkins|work=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out London]]|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/film/fuck|accessdate=April 17, 2013|title=Fuck review|date=February 10, 2009}} A critical review by Noah Sanders of ''[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]'' concluded that the film was watchable and amusing, but poorly edited and organized.{{cite news|first=Noah|last=Sanders|work=[[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]|url=http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/Content?oid=113500|title=Film: On Screen – '10 Items or Less,' 'The Beales of Grey Gardens,' and 'Fuck'|date=November 30, 2006|accessdate=April 25, 2013|location=Seattle}} The ''[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]'' criticized the film's length,{{cite news|first=Chris|last=Hewitt|work=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|title=If you're going to play around with the f-bomb, make sure it explodes|date=November 17, 2006|page=E2}} which was echoed by ''[[The Washington Post]]'',{{cite news|title=Cursing the word|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=December 1, 2006|page=T37; Section: Weekend|first=Stephen |last=Hunter}} the ''[[Deseret News]]'',{{cite news|first=Jeff|last=Vice|work=[[Deseret News]]|date=December 15, 2006|title='( F-Word )' film gets tiresome|page=W08|location=Salt Lake City}} ''[[The Herald (Everett)|The Herald]]''{{cite news|first=Robert|last=Horton|title=F-bomb documentary too freakin' unfocused|work=[[The Herald (Everett)|The Herald]]|location=Everett, Washington|date=December 1, 2006}} and the ''[[New York Daily News]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/nydn-features/short-takes-article-1.617421|title=Short Takes: Say What?|work=[[New York Daily News]]|date=November 10, 2006|first=Jack|last=Matthews|page=54}} In a review for the ''[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]'' Bill White gave the film a grade C, calling it a dull compilation of childish observations and a failed attempt to spark a discussion about freedom of speech.{{cite news|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|first=Bill|last=White|title=Limited movie runs: 'F—k'|date=November 30, 2006|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/ae/movies/article/Limited-movie-runs-F-k-1221169.php|accessdate=April 17, 2013}} Mike Pinsky of ''[[DVD Verdict]]'' concluded that the film's main arguments were achieved by the beginning of the documentary, and criticized its lack of subsequent structure and light tone overall. ===Home media=== THINKFilm reached an agreement to screen the documentary on the American [[Pay television|premium]] cable channel [[Showtime (TV channel)|Showtime]] in 2007,{{cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/2006/03/24/Documentary-explores-the-f-word/UPI-36571143258567/|title=Documentary explores the 'f-word'|author=UPI NewsTrack|agency=[[United Press International]]|date=March 24, 2006}} and it aired on the [[Documentary Channel (TV channel)|Documentary Channel]] on May 28, 2011.{{cite news|title=How to hear the F-word 857 times on TV – F**k. 2–4 a.m. Saturday. Documentary Channel.|date=May 27, 2011|work=[[The Miami Herald]]|first=Glenn|last=Garvin|quote=Anybody expecting protective bleeps will suffer lethally seared eardrums within minutes of tuning in; the program shatters all existing records of F-word usage with 857 gloriously stereophonic examples.}}{{cite news|first=Rebecca|last=Bachman|work=[[Santa Barbara Independent]]|title=Film: Documentary Digs Into the F-Bomb – Interview with the Writer and Director of the Film That Dare Not Speak Its Own Name|url=http://www.independent.com/news/2011/may/27/documentary-digs-f-bomb/|accessdate=April 25, 2013|date=May 27, 2011 }} The [[DVD]] for ''Fuck'' was released by THINKFilm on February 13, 2007,{{cite news|url=http://www.joblo.com/blu-rays-dvds/reviews/fck|accessdate=April 19, 2013|date=March 13, 2007|first=Dave|last=Davis|title=F*ck DVD Review|work=[[JoBlo]]}}{{cite news|title=F**k DVD Debuts – The f-bomb film arrives on disc in Feb.|work=[[IGN]]|first=David |last=McCutcheon|date=January 25, 2007|accessdate=April 25, 2013|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/01/25/fk-dvd-debuts }} and a United Kingdom DVD edition was released in 2009.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2009/may/24/the-wrestler-the-reader|title=Review: The Critics: Releases: Mark Kemode's DVD round-up|work=[[The Observer]]|date=May 24, 2009|first=Mark|last=Kermode|page=18; Section: Observer Review Arts Pages}} For the DVDs, THINKFilm remastered the video for ''Fuck''; it was optimized for home viewing with 1.85:1 anamorphic widescreen transfer to a 16:9 anamorphic full-frame presentation and Dolby Digital Stereo 2.0 audio. Trailers for ''[[Shortbus]]'', ''[[Farce of the Penguins]]'' and ''[[The Aristocrats (film)|The Aristocrats]]'' appear on the DVD before the documentary.{{cite news|work=[[DVD Verdict]]|url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/fuck.php|accessdate=April 19, 2013|date=March 12, 2007|first=Mike|last=Pinsky|title=DVD Verdict Review – Fuck|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927194517/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/fuck.php|archivedate=September 27, 2007|df=mdy-all}} Special features include a [[Audio commentary|commentary track]] by Steve Anderson, interviews with Anderson and Bill Plympton, the film's [[theatrical trailer]], a gallery for the introductory trailers, deleted scenes and interviews with Hunter S. Thompson and Tera Patrick.{{cite news|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/26788/fuck/|accessdate=April 19, 2013|work=[[DVD Talk]]|title=Fuck: DVD Talk Review of the DVD Video|first=Bill|last=Gibron|date=February 13, 2007}}{{cite news|work=[[MovieWeb]]|url=http://www.movieweb.com/dvd/DVwqCyxFxAC6Ax/REeKMhfgDqH5hk|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024005332/http://www.movieweb.com/dvd/DVwqCyxFxAC6Ax/REeKMhfgDqH5hk|archivedate=October 24, 2013|accessdate=April 19, 2013|title=F**k DVD|author=Mushy|date=February 16, 2007}} The disc includes an optional on-screen counter, giving viewers a running total of utterances (and appearances) of the word "fuck" during play.{{efn|The on-screen counter tracks uses of "fuck" throughout the film in aggregate over time, starting from the beginning of the film.}} ===Impact=== ''Fuck'' has been a resource for several university courses.{{efn|The film was recommended as a resource to students by Dr. Richard Stepp in his Fall 2007 course "Ethnographic and Documentary Film" at the [[University of Florida]].{{cite news|first=Richard|last=Stepp|title=Ethnographic and Documentary Film|date=Fall 2007|publisher=University of Florida|work=ANT 4930|page=4}}}}{{efn|See additional research by Miriam Sobre-Denton of [[Southern Illinois University Carbondale]] and Jana Simonis published in the [[academic journal]] ''Communication Teacher''.}} Christopher M. Fairman discussed the documentary in his article, "Fuck", published in February 2007 in the ''[[Cardozo Law Review]]''.{{cite journal|journal=[[Cardozo Law Review]]|title=Fuck|first=Christopher M.|last=Fairman|authorlink=Christopher M. Fairman|date=February 2007|url=http://works.bepress.com/christopher_fairman/12|accessdate=April 23, 2013|pages=1711–1772|volume=28|issue=4|issn=0270-5192|oclc=54471078}} Fairman cited Anderson's decision to call his film ''Fuck'' and the marketing problems this entailed, saying that he and Anderson both found the title of their works helped spur debate on [[word taboo]]s in society. In an interview with the ''Santa Barbara Independent'', Anderson said that a schoolteacher in Philadelphia had been fired for showing the documentary to his students. The teacher had researched the documentary, and wanted to teach his students the history of the word because of its frequent use in his class. Anderson said it was not the use of the word "fuck" in the film that cost the teacher his job, but a 38-second scene from a ''[[Fuck for Forest]]'' concert in Europe where a couple engaged in sexual intercourse onstage as environmental advocacy. The teacher showed the DVD to his 11th-grade journalism class at [[William Penn High School (Philadelphia)|William Penn High School]] without previewing it or sending [[permission slip]]s home to parents.{{cite news|first=Jill|last=Porter|title=The 90-minute lapse that killed a 19-year career: Showing a DVD about the F-Word in class was a mistake ... But why a fatal one?|date=October 19, 2007|work=[[Philadelphia Daily News]]}} He told the ''[[Philadelphia Daily News]]'' that before showing the documentary, he was unaware that it contained the clip showing sexual intercourse. He was dismissed from his position by the school principal, and his termination was upheld by the regional superintendent. The teacher did not appeal the decision, instead retiring. An analysis of the incident by the ''Philadelphia Daily News'' concluded that the school district's decision to fire the teacher was appropriate, but also agreed with the teacher's position that showing a 90-minute DVD should not have obliterated his 19 years as an educator. ''Fuck'' was featured in a 2012 analysis in the academic journal ''Communication Teacher'', "Do You Talk to Your Teacher with That Mouth? ''F*ck: A Documentary'' and Profanity as a Teaching Tool in the Communication Classroom", by Miriam Sobre-Denton of [[Southern Illinois University Carbondale]] and Jana Simonis. Sobre-Denton and Simonis discussed the documentary's use for [[communication studies]] students studying university-level [[intercultural relations]]. Their research incorporated interviews with Steve Anderson, students and data from [[Postgraduate education|graduate-level]] classes in language and culture. Sobre-Denton and Simonis' conclusions correlated [[taboo word]]s with social forms of power, [[rebellion|rebelliousness]], [[professional]]ism and [[gender role]]s.{{cite journal|journal=Communication Teacher|title=Do You Talk to Your Teacher with That Mouth? ''F*ck: A Documentary'' and Profanity as a Teaching Tool in the Communication Classroom|doi=10.1080/17404622.2012.659196|pages=178–193|first=Miriam ([[Southern Illinois University Carbondale]])|last=Sobre-Denton|author2=Jana Simonis |date=July 2012|volume=26|issue=3|publisher=Routledge: Taylor & Francis; [[National Communication Association]]|issn=1740-4622}} ==See also== * [[Censorship in the United States]] * ''[[Cohen v. California]]'' * [[Freedom of speech in the United States]] * [[List of films that most frequently use the word "fuck"]] * [[The F Word (2005 film)|''The F Word'' (2005 film)]] * [[Madonna on Late Show with David Letterman|Madonna on ''Late Show with David Letterman'']] {{Portal bar|Freedom of speech|Human rights|Journalism|Language|Law|Society|Supreme Court of the United States}} ==Footnotes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book|last=Allan|first=Keith|last2=Burridge|first2=Kate|authorlink=Keith Allan (linguist)|authorlink2=Kate Burridge|title=Forbidden Words: Taboo and the Censoring of Language|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2006|isbn=0-521-52564-0}} * {{cite book|last=Atkins|first=Robert|last2=Mintcheva|first2=Svetlana|title=Censoring Culture: Contemporary Threats to Free Expression|publisher=The New Press|year=2009|isbn=1-59558-050-6}} * {{cite book|last=Fairman|first=Christopher M.|authorlink=Christopher M. Fairman|title=[[Fuck: Word Taboo and Protecting Our First Amendment Liberties]]|publisher=Sphinx Publishing|year=2009|isbn=1-57248-711-9}} * {{cite book|last=Heins|first=Marjorie|authorlink=Marjorie Heins|title=[[Not in Front of the Children: 'Indecency,' Censorship, and the Innocence of Youth]]|publisher=Rutgers University Press|year=2007|isbn=0-8135-4221-9}} * {{cite book|title=[[The F-Word (book)|The F-Word]]|first=Jesse|last=Sheidlower|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|year=2009|isbn=0-19-539311-2|authorlink=Jesse Sheidlower}} ==External links== {{commons|Fuck (film)}} {{wikiquote|Fuck (film)}} {{Spoken Wikipedia|EN-Fuck (film)-article.flac|2014-02-18}} * {{cite web|title=FUCK: Four Letter Film|url=http://www.fourletterfilm.com/|work=fourletterfilm.com|accessdate=April 17, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120106210412/http://www.fourletterfilm.com/|archivedate=January 6, 2012}} * {{cite web|title=About The Filmmakers|url=http://www.fourletterfilm.com/film.html|work=fourletterfilm.com|accessdate=August 1, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070102060812/http://www.fourletterfilm.com/film.html|archivedate=January 2, 2007}} * {{AFI film|63831|Fuck}} * {{IMDb title|0486585|Fuck}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|id=fuck|title=Fuck}} * {{metacritic film|id=fuck|title=Fuck}} * {{oclc| 85793984}}; {{oclc|232578834}}, {{oclc|755910041}} * ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20131023011536/http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/fuck/ Fuck]'' at [[Yahoo!
