{{Infobox video game | title = Grey Goo | image = File:Greygoo-cover-art.jpg | caption = | developer = [[Petroglyph Games]]<ref name=FAQ>{{cite web|title=Grey Goo FAQ|url=https://www.greybox.com/greygoo/en/info/faq/|website=GreyBox.com|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref> | publisher = Grey Box<ref name=FAQ /> | director = | designer = Andrew Zoboki<ref name=GamespotReview>{{cite web|title=Grey Goo, and the Rise, Fall, and Rise of the RTS|url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/grey-goo-and-the-rise-fall-and-rise-of-the-rts/1100-6418604/|accessdate=28 March 2014}}</ref> | programmer = | artist = | engine = GlyphX | writer = | composer = [[Frank Klepacki]]<ref name=GreyGooSoundtrack>{{cite web|title=Grey Goo - Creating the Soundtrack|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VHDoudEsMsI|website=YouTube|publisher=[[Petroglyph Games]]|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref> | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]]<ref name=FAQ /> | released = January 23, 2015<ref name=releasedate>{{cite web|title=GREY GOO LAUNCH DATE ANNOUNCED|url=https://www.greybox.com/greygoo/en/news/grey-goo-launch-date-announced/|website=Greybox.com|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref> | genre = [[Real-time strategy]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |producer = Six Foot}} '''''Grey Goo''''' is a [[science fiction]] [[real-time strategy]] video game [[video game developer|developed]] by [[Petroglyph Games]], produced by Six Foot, and [[video game publisher|published]] by Grey Box on January 23, 2015<ref name=releasedate /> for [[Microsoft Windows]].<ref name=FAQ /> It features a playable faction based on the [[grey goo]] scenario.
==Gameplay== In ''Grey Goo'' players can choose one of three playable factions, the Humans, the Beta, or the Goo,<ref name=GreyGooGameInfo>{{cite web|title=Grey Goo Game Info |url=https://www.greybox.com/greygoo/en/info/ |website=GreyBox.com |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150412165124/https://www.greybox.com/greygoo/en/info/ |archivedate=April 12, 2015 }}</ref> and use them to complete a [[single-player video game|single-player]] campaign or play in a competitive [[multi-player video game|multiplayer]] [[game mechanics#modes|mode]] [[player versus player|versus other players]]. Each faction features a unique set of units, structures, and play style as well as its own segment of the single-player campaign. The Beta faction relies on speed, mobility, and power to dominate the battle through battle machines and specific units able to mount themselves on "hard-points" for defense. The human faction is well-rounded and highly based on reconfiguration of their base. They possess teleportation technology, able to reconfigure their sentinels and other structures and also transport their units to anywhere on the battlefield. The Goo faction features the game's namesake, self replicating nanobots that can move around the map consuming enemies and forming themselves into new units. Due to this, they only rely on pure strength and speed to destroy anything in their way. The game bases itself around "macro decisions over micro management" and features a qwert hotkey system for unit control and construction.<ref name=GreyGooReveal>{{cite web|last1=Zacny|first1=Rob|title=Grey Goo exclusive reveal: a throwback RTS that emphasizes macro decisions over micro management|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/grey-goo-preview/|website=PCGamer|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref> Also, maps feature terrain obstructing vision similar to games such as ''[[Defense of the Ancients|DotA]]'' and ''[[League of Legends]]''.<ref name=GreyGooRTS-IGN>{{cite web|last1=Hafer|first1=T.J.|title=GREY GOO: AN UNCLEAN RTS (IN A GOOD WAY)|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/12/15/grey-goo-an-unclean-rts-in-a-good-way|website=IGN|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
==Plot== The story takes place 500 years after humans first ventured outside of the [[Solar System|solar system]]. The Beta (or ''Mora'', as they call themselves), a once-spacefaring culture, has fled with the remainder of their civilization to Ecosystem 9 (which they call ''Falkannan''), the planet the game takes place on, from an unknown threat they call the Silent Ones. During a test firing of the [[wormhole]] they meant to use to return to the stars, they are attacked by enemies coming through the portal, or "Keyhole". These advanced [[Unmanned Combat Vehicle|drone]] units are first suspected to belong to the Silent Ones but are later revealed to be human in origin. As the conflict between the Beta settlers, led by Aran (Commander) Saruk, and the human forces intensifies, an explosion in orbit scatters wreckage all over their colony, from which the [[Grey goo|Goo]] emerge and attack both sides.
After a long history of war and exploration in space, during which no intelligent life was found, humans had returned to planet Earth in an attempt to seek peace and stability in a [[Post-scarcity economy|post-scarcity]] society guided by [[Artificial intelligence|AI]]. A signal is detected from the distant planet Ecosystem 9 in the outer [[Scutum–Centaurus Arm|Crux Arm]], and the starship ''LSV Darwin'', captained by Lucy Tak, is sent to investigate. Landing forces are engaged by the Beta (who are designated as such by the humans because their original planet was the "beta candidate" for intelligent life during previous [[Search for extraterrestrial intelligence|radio telescope surveys]], but subsequent investigation did not receive any more signals — likely a consequence of the Silent Ones' attack) and collect samples from the surface, including Goo, which promptly escapes and destroys the ''Darwin'', reaching the Beta colony site in the re-entering wreckage. Despite their initial conflict, the Beta and the now-stranded humans agree to an alliance to destroy the Goo that threatens them, which is revealed to be part of the artificially intelligent "''Pathfinder''" [[Self-replicating spacecraft|Von Neumann probe]] system sent from Earth centuries prior to chart the galaxy in advance of the human expansion. The probes were believed to have been decommissioned when exploration was abandoned, but presumably the Goo on Ecosystem 9 somehow altered its own programming, becoming self-directing.
After sacrificing himself to destroy what was believed to be the last Goo on the planet, the robotic human commander Singleton's consciousness merges with the Goo. It is revealed that the Goo are attempting not to consume life, but rather to protect it from "the growing shroud of Silence" that is expanding across the [[Milky Way|galaxy]] — the same unknown force that destroyed the Beta civilization. All previous hostile actions were merely attempts to expand in order to effectively defend the planet. With Singleton's assistance, the Goo fights back from the brink of extinction and carves a path to the Beta's Keyhole device in the hope of contacting and reuniting with the scattered Goo across the galaxy, to stand united against the Silence. Singleton attempts to negotiate with the Humans and Beta, but the Goo is forced to destroy the opposing armies. Defeated, Saruk, Tak and others who were spared watch as countless Goo masses emerge from Keyholes across the planet. In an after-credits scene it is hinted that the "growing silence" has discovered Ecosystem 9.
==Release== ''Grey Goo'' was originally announced on March 13, 2014, with a release slated for fall 2014.<ref name=PetroglyphIntroduces>{{cite web|last1=Cavalli|first1=Earnest|title=Petroglyph introduces RTS Grey Goo with brief teaser, screenshots|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2014/03/13/petroglyph-introduces-rts-grey-goo-with-brief-teaser-screenshot/|website=Joystiq|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref><ref name=PetroglyphAnnounces>{{cite web|last1=Macy|first1=Seth|title=PETROGLYPH ANNOUNCES NEW RTS GREY GOO|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/03/13/petroglyph-announces-new-rts-grey-goo|website=IGN|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref> This date was pushed back, and the game was released on January 23, 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Grey Goo on Steam|url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/290790|website=store.steampowered.com|accessdate = 2015-09-17}}</ref>
The [[downloadable content|DLC]] pack ''Emergence'', containing three new single player [[level (video games)|missions]], was released on June 11, 2015. The missions are centered on the robotic human commander Singleton, and how he became the guiding consciousness of the Goo following the events of the main human campaign.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Discover "Emergence" Grey Goo's new DLC - News|url = https://www.greybox.com/greygoo/en/news/discover-emergence-grey-goos-new-dlc/|website = www.greybox.com|accessdate = 2015-06-29}}</ref>
The DLC pack ''The Descent of the Shroud'', containing new single player missions, was released on February 1, 2016. The missions are set months after the game finishes, where it introduces a new faction, The Shroud, also called The Silent Ones.
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 77/100<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/grey-goo |title=Grey Goo for PC |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=19 June 2016}}</ref> <!-- Reviewers --> | GSpot = 8/10<ref>{{cite web|last1=Todd|first1=Brett|title=Grey Goo Review|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/grey-goo-review/1900-6416017/|publisher=Gamespot|accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref> | IGN = 7,6/10<ref>{{cite web|title=Grey Goo Review|url=http://www.ign.com/games/grey-goo/pc-20014601|publisher=IGN|accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref> | PCGUS = 82/100<ref>{{cite web|last1=Birnbaum|first1=Ian|title=Grey Goo|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/grey-goo-review/|publisher=PCGamer|accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref> | rev1 = ''[[Hardcore Gamer]]'' | rev1Score = 4/5<ref name="hardcore gamer review">{{cite web|url=http://www.hardcoregamer.com/2015/02/08/review-grey-goo/133271/|title=Review: Grey Goo |work=Hardcore Gamer|publisher=Hardcore Gamer|first=Bradly|last=Storm|date= 8 February 2014|accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> | rev2 = ''[[HonestGamers]]'' | rev2Score = 8/10<ref name="HonestGamers review">{{cite web|url=http://www.honestgamers.com/12476/pc/grey-goo/review.html|title=Review: Grey Goo |work=HonestGamers|publisher=HonestGamers|first=Gary|last=Hartley|date= 8 February 2015|accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> | rev3 = ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' | rev3Score = 7/10<ref>{{cite web|title=Grey Goo review – get stuck into the strategy|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/01/26/grey-goo-review-get-stuck-into-the-strategy-5035998/|accessdate=17 January 2016|publisher=Metro}}</ref> | rev4 = ''[[GameWatcher]]'' | rev4Score = 8/10<ref name="GameWatcher review">{{cite web|title=Grey Goo Review|url=http://www.gamewatcher.com/reviews/grey-goo-review/12124|publisher=GameWatcher|accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref> }} {{expand section|date=May 2015}} ''[[Hardcore Gamer]]'' gave the game a 4 out of 5, stating: "''Grey Goo'' is a stand-out RTS that has found an expert way of blending old with new to create something familiar but fresh. Fans of old-school real-time strategy classics such as ''[[Command & Conquer]]'' will find much to love here".<ref name="hardcore gamer review" /> HonestGamers gave the game an 8 out of 10, opining it is "a reinvention of how RTS games used to be, looking back on that time when you’d send harvesters out to collect spice and hoped to hell a [[sandworm (dune)|sandworm]] didn't eat the bloody thing, or when you geared up to take on that [[Kane (Command & Conquer)|one bald guy]] from [[Brotherhood of Nod|Nod]]. Just in this case, the production values have been ramped up, and it hates you just a little bit more".<ref name="HonestGamers review" /> GameWatcher scored it 8.0, saying that Grey Goo is "probably Petroglyph’s best game (especially if you’re not a Star Wars fan), it won’t steal the RTS crown from Blizzard or Creative Assembly but if you want a straight fun strategy you won’t regret being absorbed by Grey Goo".<ref name="GameWatcher review" />

{{refimprove|date=September 2014}} {{Haitian Vodou}}
[[Haitian Vodou]] is a [[syncretism|syncretic mixture]] of [[Roman Catholic]] rituals developed during the [[French colonial empire|French colonial period]], based on [[Traditional African religion|traditional African beliefs]], with roots in [[Dahomey mythology|Dahomey]], [[Kingdom of Kongo|Kongo]] and [[Yoruba mythology|Yoruba]] traditions, and folkloric influence from the indigenous [[Taíno people|Taino]] peoples of [[Haiti]]. The [[Loa]], or spirits with whom Vodouisants work and practice, are not gods but servants of the Supreme Creator Bondye (pronounced Bon Dieu). In keeping with the French-Catholic influence of the faith, vodousaints are for the most part monotheists, believing that the Loa are great and powerful forces in the world with whom humans interact and vice versa, resulting in a symbiotic relationship intended to bring both humans and the Loa back to Bondye. "Vodou is a religious practice, a faith that points toward an intimate knowledge of God, and offers its practitioners a means to come into communion with the Divine, through an ever evolving paradigm of dance, song and prayers."<ref>{{cite book|last=Vye Zo Komande LaMenfo|first=Mambo|title=Serving the Spirits: The Religion of Vodou|year=2011|publisher=Mambo Vye Zo Komande LaMenfo|location=United States|isbn= 978-0615535241|page=12}}</ref>
== Related notions ==
* Asagwe - Haitian Vodou dancing used to honor the Loa. * Avalou - ("supplication") Haitian Vodou dance. * Coco macaque - Haitian Vodou implement. It is a stick, which is supposed to be able to walk on its own. The owner of a coco macaque can send it on errands. If it is used to hit an enemy, the enemy will die before the dawn. * Gangan, [[Houngan]] - Haitian priests. They lead the peoples in dancing, drumming, and singing to invoke the Loa. * [[Ghede]] - family of spirits related to death and fertility. * [[Guinee]] - Haitian afterlife. It is also where life began and the home of their spirits. * [[Loa]] - Haitian Vodou spirit. * [[Mambo (Vodou)|Mambo]] - Haitian priestess who, together with the Houngan, leads the Vodou rituals and invokes the Loa. * [[Paquet congo]] - charms made of organic matter wrapped in cloth, intended to rouse the Loa. * [[Petro loa|Petro]] - aggressive and warlike family of spirits * [[Rada loa|Rada]] - old, benefic family of spirits * [[Tonton Macoute (disambiguation)|Tonton Macoute]], a Haitian mythological phrase meaning "bogey man" (literally: "Uncle [[Sack Man|Bagman]]") * Ville au Camp - ("House in the Fields") the underwater capital of the Loa
== See also == * [[Haitian Vodou]] * [[Culture of Haiti]] * [[Religion in Haiti]] * [[Haitian art]] * [[Veve]], a religious symbol commonly used in Vodou and [[Palo (religion)|Palo]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Hanazuki: Full of Treasures | image = Hanazuki Full of Treasures logo.png | show_name_2 = Hanazuki | genre = <!-- Must be reliably sourced --> | based_on = {{based on|The characters|Hanneke Metselaar and Nicola Stumpo}} | director = Allison Craig | voices = {{plainlist| * [[Jessica DiCicco]] * [[Colleen Villard|Colleen O'Shaunessey]] * [[Cassandra Morris]] * [[Michael Sinterniklaas]] * [[Avery Waddell|Avery Kidd Waddell]] }} | composer = {{plainlist| * John Jennings Boyd * Eric V. Hachikian }} | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 27 | list_episodes = #Episodes | executive_producer = {{plainlist| * Stephen Davis * [[Chris Prynoski]] }} | producer = Winnie Chaffee | editor = Louis Legge | runtime = 10–11 minutes | company = {{plainlist| * [[Titmouse, Inc.]] * [[Hasbro Studios]] * Inspidea {{small| (animation service)}} }} | distributor = Hasbro Studios | network = [[Discovery Family]] (2018-) | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[16:9]] [[HDTV]]) | first_aired = {{Start date|2017|1|12}} | last_aired = {{End date|present}} | website = http://www.hasbro.com/en-us/brands/hanazuki | website_title = Official website }} '''''Hanazuki: Full of Treasures''''' is an American [[Animated series|animated]] children's [[web show]] produced by [[Titmouse, Inc.]] for [[Hasbro Studios]], with Stephen Davis of Hasbro Studios and [[Chris Prynoski]] of Titmouse serving as executive producers. Made in conjunction with a line of ''Hanazuki'' toys, it is based on characters and concepts which were developed by Hanneke Metselaar and Niko Stumpo before [[Hasbro]] purchased them in 2010. Set in a fictional galaxy comprising countless moons, the series follows Hanazuki, a childlike being called a Moonflower who uses her emotion-based powers to protect her home from being obliterated by a dark force known as the "Big Bad".
The series debuted on [[YouTube]] on January 12, 2017,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickeringmyth.com/2017/01/hasbro-studios-launches-first-animated-digital-series-hanazuki-full-of-treasures|title=Hasbro Studios launches first animated digital series Hanazuki Full of Treasures|first=Gary|last=Collinson|work=Flickering Myth|date=January 12, 2017|accessdate=January 12, 2017}}</ref> and was produced in conjunction with a line of merchandise to be released later the same year, including a toyline and digital app.<ref name="press">{{cite press release|date=January 12, 2017|title=Hasbro Invites You to Discover a New World Full of Treasures with HANAZUKI|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20170112005150/en/Hasbro-Invites-Discover-World-Full-Treasures-HANAZUKI|location=Pawtucket, Rhode Island|publisher=Hasbro|agency=Business Wire|accessdate=May 9, 2017}}</ref> The web series received praise from critics, drawing favorable comparisons to other animated series such as ''[[My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic]]'' and ''[[Steven Universe]]'' for its storytelling, visual aesthetic, and darker undertones.<ref name="mlp"/><ref name="bsckids"/><ref name="idt"/> As of May 2017, the series has amassed over 120 million views.<ref name="s2"/> It has been renewed for a second season, which will premiere in 2018.<ref name="s2"/> A third season and a feature-length film are also in development.<ref name="movie"/>
''Hanazuki'' began airing on [[Discovery Family]] on December 1, 2018, marking its American televised debut.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/kemo5791/status/1061490964819206144|title=Kamal Walker on Twitter|website=Twitter|language=en|access-date=2018-11-13}}</ref>
==Premise== The series is set in a fictional galaxy of moons that is beset by the "Big Bad", a black, inky miasma that drains the life and color of anything it touches. Each moon is protected by a Moonflower, a plantlike child who uses his or her emotional states to activate magical "treasures" that are supplied by an infantile being named Little Dreamer, which can then be planted to grow trees that ward off the Big Bad. The series opens with Hanazuki, a newly born Moonflower, arriving on a moon populated by numerous denizens, including colorful rabbit-like creatures called Hemka. Several episodes focus on Hanazuki and her friends' escapades as she learns about her responsibilities and emotions, ending with her growing a colored Treasure Tree that corresponds with her mood in that episode. As the series progresses, Hanazuki encounters other Moonflowers that have failed at saving their own moons and seek to learn from Hanazuki in order to properly harness their powers against the Big Bad.<ref name="animag"/>
==Characters== ===Moonflowers=== Moonflowers are childlike beings who are guardians of the galaxy's moons. Created by Little Dreamer, they have white flowers on their heads and highlights that change color depending on their moods, enabling them to grow Treasure Trees that protect their moons from the Big Bad.
* '''Hanazuki''' ([[Jessica DiCicco]]) – The main character of the series. A newly born Moonflower, Hanazuki is a kind, friendly, and optimistic girl who always offers help to those who need it. She is quick to adapt to her role as her moon's guardian, allowing her to understand and control her own emotions more successfully than most other Moonflowers. * '''Kiazuki''' ([[Cassandra Lee Morris]]) – An older, cynical Moonflower who lives on a moon ravaged by the Big Bad. Although claiming to be more experienced than Hanazuki, Kiazuki has failed to ever grow a colored Treasure Tree of her own, and envies Hanazuki's success. She thus manipulates Hanazuki, who admires her as her "Moonflower sister", into helping her acquire treasures to restore her moon. She is later revealed to be the founder of the Garlandians, a failed emergency response team devised to combat the Big Bad. * '''Kiyoshi''' (Vargus Mason) – A male Moonflower who protects a moon inhabited by unicorns. Because of his pessimistic nature, he is only able to grow black Treasure Trees, which are ineffective in warding off the Big Bad. Deposed and exiled for his failures, Kiyoshi receives guidance from Hanazuki to properly harness his emotional powers, eventually regaining authority of his moon. * '''Maroshi''' ([[Marcus Toji]]) – A Moonflower from an ocean-covered world that is frozen and shattered by the Big Bad. Despite losing his home, he maintains a positive, laid-back attitude at all times, which makes him easy for others to get along with, but also appearing somewhat irresponsible. He is talented at flying through space on a [[surfboard]]-like device.<!-- * '''Miyumi''' (Elise Dubois) -->
===Hemka=== The Hemka (or Hemkas) are small, rabbit-like creatures that inhabit Hanazuki's moon. They speak in gibberish that others except Hanazuki can fully understand, and they have malleable bodies that allow them to merge and change into different objects. Each Hemka is of a different color and represents a specific personality trait that Hanazuki reflects.
* '''Red Hemka''' ([[Colleen Villard]]) – A feisty Hemka prone to picking fights and pulling pranks on others. * '''Orange Hemka''' ([[Michael Sinterniklaas]]) – A wacky Hemka who often jumps around and makes silly faces. * '''Yellow Hemka''' (Colleen Villard) – A happy Hemka who enjoys playing and remains optimistic in dangerous situations. * '''Lime Green Hemka''' (Jessica DiCicco) – A scared Hemka who is easily startled by anything. * '''Dark Green Hemka''' (Michael Sinterniklaas) – A mellow Hemka who speaks with a laid-back tone. * '''Teal Hemka''' (Michael Sinterniklaas in season 1, Cassandra Lee Morris in the shorts) – A glamorous Hemka. * '''Blue Hemka''' (Jessica DiCicco) – A sad Hemka who is constantly crying or on the verge of tears. * '''Lavender Hemka''' (Michael Sinterniklaas) – An inspired Hemka who has creative ideas but is too shy to act on them. * '''Purple Hemka''' (Michael Sinterniklaas) – A courageous Hemka who performs feats of derring-do. * '''Pink Hemka''' (Michael Sinterniklaas) – A loving Hemka who shows affection for everything. * '''Raspberry Hemka''' (Cassandra Lee Morris) * '''Emerald Hemka''' ([[Avery Waddell]])
===Unicorns=== [[Unicorn|Unicorns]] in the series are native to Kiyoshi's moon. They possess the same colors and personality traits as the Hemka, with the additional ability to perform [[Magic (paranormal)|magic]] using their horns. Most unicorns in the series are voiced by [[Debi Derryberry]].
* '''Sleepy Unicorn''' (Avery Waddell) – A unicorn who lives on Hanazuki's moon and, as his name suggests, spends most of his time sleeping. Despite his relaxed and lazy nature, he harbors a troubled past; originally named Noble Unicorn, he lives in exile from his home moon after failing to stop his brother Twisted Unicorn's revolt against Kiyoshi. Convinced that he is unfit to wield magic because of his failure, Sleepy regains his confidence to use his powers again to help Hanazuki. * '''Twisted Unicorn''' (Avery Waddell) – Sleepy Unicorn's brother and the leader of the unicorns. Twisted is a tyrant responsible for overthrowing Kiyoshi, forcing his fellow unicorns to maintain a force field he professes will protect their moon from the Big Bad. He is eventually deposed by the combined efforts of Hanazuki, Kiyoshi, and their allies, leading Twisted to hunt them across the galaxy for revenge.
===Others=== * '''Little Dreamer''' (Colleen Villard) – Hanazuki's infant-like creator who delivers treasures to the Moonflowers. He is shown sleeping at all times and wearing different-patterned pajamas almost every time he appears. * '''Dazzlessence Jones''' (Avery Waddell) – The self-appointed [[sheriff]] of Hanazuki's moon who resembles a [[Diamond (gemstone)|diamond]]. He helps Hanazuki maintain order, and speaks verbose words through song. * '''Zikoro''' (Avery Waddell) – Kiazuki's sole companion on her moon, a black creature who behaves like a restless dog. He is regularly mistreated by Kiazuki, but remains loyal to her and enjoys tormenting the Hemka. After Kiazuki abandons him on Hanazuki's moon, he takes more of a liking to Hanazuki and her friends. * '''Chicken Plant''' (Alison Martin) – A grouchy plant with the resemblance of a chicken that constantly tries eating the Hemka. She is prone to laying eggs that hatch into destructive monsters. * '''Mirror Plant''' (Shondalia White) – A plant that translates an individual's thoughts and repeats what the subject says. * '''Mazzadril''' (Michael Sinterniklaas) – One-eyed, four-legged beasts with horns on their heads and tentacles for mouths. Their natural habitat is the dark side of both Hanazuki's moon and Kiazuki's moon. * '''Doughy Bunington''' ([[Pat Fraley]]) – A friendly [[gourmand]] hotdog who lives on the dark side of the moon, exiled there after thoughtlessly devouring Chicken Plant's wings. * '''Basil Ganglia''' ([[Trevor Devall]]) – An egocentric, megalomaniacal brain who inhabits a cave on the moon's dark side. He has designs to take over Hanazuki's moon, but is helpless to carry them out due to his lack of other body parts. * '''Flochi''' ([[Nika Futterman]]) – The creatures that inhabit Maroshi's moon, resembling fish with catlike faces. They glide across any surface in unison, with the exception of a lavender Flochi aptly named Wanderer for her more independent nature.<!-- * '''Sloths''' * '''Axo''' (Gary Williams)<ref>https://twitter.com/Chevistian1/status/1037174288359596036</ref> * '''Enormous Coal''' ([[Dino Andrade]])<ref>https://twitter.com/Chevistian1/status/1037157969841082368</ref> * '''Ooh La La Love''' ([[Jennifer Hale]])<ref>https://twitter.com/Chevistian1/status/1037180146908913665</ref>-->
==Development and production== {{Expand section|1=''Hanazuki'' before Hasbro's acquisition in 2010|small=no|date=September 2017}} The original concept of ''Hanazuki'' was first developed in 2005 as an independent toy line by Norwegian<ref>http://fitc.ca/speaker/nikostumpo/</ref><ref>https://thefwa.com/digital-pioneers/niko-stumpo</ref> art director Niko Stumpo and his Dutch partner, Hanneke Metselaar,<ref name="announce">{{cite web|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Hasbro Launching Girl-Focused Franchise With Digital Series First (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/hasbro-launching-girl-focused-toy-franchise-hanazuki-962983|publisher=Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=February 19, 2017|date=January 10, 2017}}</ref> under the self-formed Hanazuki Company in the Netherlands.<ref name="about">{{cite web|title=Thisisarobot: About Us|url=http://love.thisisarobot.com/about/|website=Thisisarobot|accessdate=February 19, 2017}}</ref> [[Hasbro]] purchased the rights to the ''Hanazuki'' brand in 2010, with The Hanazuki Company being rebranded Thisisarobot.<ref name="about"/> By 2013, ''Hanazuki'' was being developed as an interactive game for children from ages 7 to 12, with a scheduled release date for Fall 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pavlika|first1=Holly|title=A Digital Way for Your Child to Deal with Their Bad Dreams|url=http://www.momentumnation.com/a-digital-way-for-your-child-to-deal-with-their-bad-dreams/|website=MOMentumNation|accessdate=February 19, 2017|date=May 21, 2013}}</ref> A preview of Hanazuki was included in the 2013 United States home media release of [[Hasbro Studios]]' ''[[My Little Pony: Equestria Girls (film)|My Little Pony: Equestria Girls]]''.<ref>http://www.toonzone.net/review-little-pony-equestria-girls-blu-ray-slow-canter-not-galloping-success/</ref> On January 10, 2017, Hasbro announced ''Hanazuki'' as a [[web series]] that would premiere on their YouTube channel on January 12.<ref name="announce"/>
The web-series was produced by Titmouse, Inc. for Hasbro Studios, with animation service provided by Inspidea in Malaysia.

===Season 2 (2018)=== A second season was announced on May 9, 2017, and is scheduled to premiere in 2018.<ref name="s2">{{cite web|last1=Robertson|first1=Andy|title=Hasbro's 'Hanazuki' Toys, Tech And Cartoons Build Children's Emotional Literacy|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andyrobertson/2017/05/09/hasbros-hanazuki-toys-tech-and-cartoons-build-childrens-emotional-literacy/|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=May 9, 2017|date=May 9, 2017}}</ref>
===Season 3 (2019)=== A third season was announced on August 3, 2017 during investor day and will premiere sometime in 2019.<ref name="movie"/>

After trying to mimic Basil Ganglia and the Pyramid with a Face, Doughy is delighted to realize he is feeling hungry again and goes back to eating. | LineColor = }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 6 | Title = Zikoro's Treasure | DirectedBy = Allison Craig and Brian Muelhaupt | WrittenBy = Whitney Ralls | Aux3 = 2:36 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|6|16}} | ShortSummary = Zikoro plays with a treasure discarded by Kiazuki after another failed attempt to grow it, later keeping it for himself when Kiazuki turns red with anger and comes looking for it. | LineColor = }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 7 | Title = You Owe Me One | DirectedBy = Allison Craig and Brian Muelhaupt | WrittenBy = Katie Chilson | Aux3 = 2:36 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|6|16}} | ShortSummary = Kiazuki struggles to get Zikoro down from atop a Treasure Tree by herself. Reluctant to ask for help outright, she begins doing favors for others around the moon so they may owe her a favor in return. Once the others help her save Zikoro, Hanazuki tells Kiazuki she can simply ask for their help in the future. | LineColor = }} {{Episode list | EpisodeNumber = 8 | Title = Dazzlecize! | DirectedBy = Allison Craig and Brian Muelhaupt | WrittenBy = Whitney Ralls | Aux3 = 2:37 | OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2018|6|16}} | ShortSummary = Dazzlessence exercises together with Orange, Pink, Dark Green, Teal, and Yellow Hemka. | LineColor = }} }}
==Release== Released beginning on January 12, 2017 on the property's official website and by Hasbro's official YouTube channel, the first season consists of 27 episodes, with the first 18 released in two sets of nine in accordance with the [[full moon]] of the [[lunar calendar]].<ref name="announce"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Trumbore|first1=David|title=Hasbro’s Kid-Friendly Digital Series ‘Hanazuki: Full of Treasures’ Is Out of This World|url=http://collider.com/hanazuki-review/|publisher=Collider|accessdate=February 19, 2017|date=January 12, 2017}}</ref> The remaining nine episodes were released weekly from May 19 to July 14, 2017.<ref name="s2"/>
In [[Canada]], ''Hanazuki: Full of Treasures'' aired as a sneak peek on January 28, 2017 on [[YTV (TV channel)|YTV]], [[Teletoon]], [[Cartoon Network (Canada)|Cartoon Network]] and [[Disney Channel (Canada)|Disney Channel]], all operated by [[Corus Entertainment]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.zap2it.com/tvlistings/ZCSGrid.do?stnNum=76221&channel=98|title=Cartoon Network Canada|work=[[Screener (website)|Screener]]|accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.zap2it.com/tvlistings/ZCSGrid.do?stnNum=96509&channel=284&aid=zap2it|title=Disney Channel Canada|work=[[Screener (website)|Screener]]|accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.zap2it.com/tvlistings/ZCSGrid.do?stnNum=76405&channel=622&aid=zap2it|title=Teletoon HD (Pacific)|work=[[Screener (website)|Screener]]|accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tvlistings.zap2it.com/tvlistings/ZCSGrid.do?stnNum=12045|title=YTV|work=[[Screener (website)|Screener]]|accessdate=January 25, 2017}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=Sources cited here are from a listings website. Better cite news report(s) instead.|date=November 2017}}
In the United States, [[Discovery Family]] began broadcasting the first season on December 1, 2018.<ref name=":1" />
==Other media== The web series was made in conjunction with a line of ''Hanazuki'' toys first announced at the 2017 New York Toy Fair, which will launch in June the same year.<ref name="s2"/><ref name="press"/> A digital app for the series was released for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] on April 4, 2017, offering a tie-in interactive video game along with episodes of the web series.<ref name="s2"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Sholtz|first1=Matthew|title=Hasbro just released Hanazuki, an odd game about moons, moods, and magic|url=http://www.androidpolice.com/2017/04/04/hasbro-just-released-hanazuki-odd-game-moons-moods-magic/|publisher=Android Police|accessdate=May 9, 2017|date=April 4, 2017}}</ref> A companion book authored by Brandon T. Snider, titled ''Hanazuki: Book of Treasures – The Official Guide'', was released on November 7, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hanazuki: Book of Treasures: The Official Guide|url=https://www.amazon.com/Hanazuki-Book-Treasures-Official-Guide/dp/1419729330|website=Amazon|accessdate=May 9, 2017}}</ref> A series of four chapter books set within the universe of the web-series was also announced, with the first book written by Stacy Davidowitz, titled ''Hanazuki: A Spark in the Dark'', released on May 8, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hanazuki: A Spark in the Dark|url=https://www.amazon.com/Hanazuki-Spark-Dark-Chapter-Books/dp/141972942X|website=Amazon|accessdate=June 15, 2018}}</ref>
===Theatrical run=== A ''Hanazuki'' short was released theatrically with Hasbro Studio's ''[[My Little Pony: The Movie (2017 film)|My Little Pony: The Movie]]'' on October 6, 2017,<ref name="CatNewsServ">{{cite news|last1=McAleer|first1=Joseph|title=Movie Review: My Little Pony: The Movie|url=http://www.catholicnews.com/services/englishnews/2017/my-little-pony-the-movie.cfm|accessdate=16 November 2017|agency=[[Catholic News Service]]|date=October 6, 2017}}</ref> the plot of which focuses on Hanazuki as she tries to get a treasure back from the playful Yellow Hemka. During Hasbro's investor day on August 3, 2017, an animated feature based on the series was announced to be in early stages of development, set to be released by [[Paramount Pictures]].<ref name="movie">{{cite web|author=Takao|title=Hasbro unveils Littlest Pet Shop Unleashed and Equestria Girls YouTube series|url=http://www.toonbarn.com/other-cartoons/hasbro-unveils-littlest-pet-shop-unleashed-equestria-girls-youtube-series|website=ToonBarn|accessdate=August 8, 2017|date=August 7, 2017}}</ref>
==Reception== ''Hanazuki: Full of Treasures'' was met with critical praise and online popularity upon release, with several favorably comparing it to the television series ''[[My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic]]'' (another Hasbro property) and ''[[Steven Universe]]'' for its light-hearted tone, visual aesthetic, and methodical storytelling.<ref name="mlp"/><ref name="bsckids"/><ref name="idt"/> As of May 2017, the series has accumulated over 120 million views on [[YouTube]].<ref name="s2"/>
In her review of the web series, Lauren Orsini of ''[[Forbes]]'' commented on the involvement of ''Friendship Is Magic'' writer [[Dave Polsky]] as a story editor, considering ''Friendship Is Magic'' to be lucrative to Hasbro's success, and concluding that the series was an attempt by the company to incite similar success with ''Hanazuki''.<ref name="mlp">{{cite web|last1=Orsini|first1=Lauren|title=Hasbro's 'Hanazuki': An Intergalactic Love Letter To 'My Little Pony' Fans|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/laurenorsini/2017/01/13/hasbros-hanazuki-an-intergalactic-love-letter-to-my-little-pony-fans/#32b130e522a8|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=May 9, 2017|date=January 13, 2017}}</ref> In a later article, Orsini attributed the series' popularity on YouTube to its "spunky characters and high production values".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Orsini|first1=Lauren|title=Take A First Look At The Next Wave Of 'Hanazuki: Full Of Treasures'|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/laurenorsini/2017/03/09/an-exclusive-first-look-at-the-next-wave-of-hanazuki-full-of-treasures/|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=May 9, 2017|date=March 9, 2017}}</ref> Mercedes Milligan of ''[[Animation Magazine]]'' said of the series, "''Hanazuki'' puts a modern, cross-platform spin on a premise that will be familiar to '80s kids who grew up with Rainbow Brite, et al."<ref name="animag">{{cite web|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/top-stories/hasbros-hanazuki-is-a-new-digital-treasure/|title=Hasbro’s ‘Hanazuki’ Is a New Digital Treasure|first=Mercedes|last=Milligan|work=Animation Magazine|date=January 12, 2017|accessdate=March 13, 2017}}</ref> Ella Anders of BSC Kids praised the opening episodes for its setting, lore, characters, and overarching storytelling. She additionally interpreted the series as a Western [[magical girl]] series that "doesn't play off the traditional magical girl path or tropes".<ref name="bsckids">{{cite web|last1=Anders|first1=Ella|title=First Look and Review of Hasbro’s Newest Series "Hanazuki Full of Treasures"|url=http://www.bsckids.com/2017/01/first-look-and-review-of-hasbros-newest-series-hanazuki-full-of-treasures/|website=BSC Kids|accessdate=May 9, 2017|date=January 12, 2017}}</ref> Nathalie Medina of ''[[IBT Media|iDigitalTimes]]'' gave the series a score of 4 out of 5, complimenting the characters and hints of a more complex underlying story, and comparing its visual style to "a Lisa Frank folder with a 2000s aesthetic".<ref name="idt">{{cite web|last1=Medina|first1=Nathalie|title='Hanazuki Full of Treasures' Review: Hasbro's Newest Addition To 'My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic' Stable Of Girl Toons|url=http://www.idigitaltimes.com/hanazuki-full-treasures-review-hasbros-newest-addition-my-little-pony-friendship-577902|publisher=iDigitalTimes|accessdate=May 9, 2017|date=January 12, 2017}}</ref>
